performer.perf_description: Equally influenced by '60s soul music and '80s post-punk rock, Afghan Whigs have released several rock albums, the last of which was 1998's '1965.' After breaking up in 2001, The Afghan Whigs' 2012 tour marks 25 years after their first live show in 1987. The group's first new recording released since getting back together is 'See and Don't See,' and their second new recording is a cover of Frank Ocean's 'Lovecrimes.'

Singer, songwriter, poet, multi-instrumentalist, feminist, successful record label owner -- Ani DiFranco's fierce independence and staggering talent have won her rabid fans the world over. Between studio and live recordings, the Buffalo native has released more than 20 albums; her latest is studio album is "Binary."

Fusing folk-rock, world beat, jazz and pop, the Dave Matthews Band is arguably the most musically adept of all its contemporaries. Formed in 1991, the group have multiple studio albums and a myriad of live releases, selling over 31 million albums worldwide. A new studio album is planned for summer 2018.
performer.perf_keywords: Grammy Awards; VH1 Awards; Under The Table and Dreaming; Crash

performer.perf_description: Cleveland-born David Wilcox is an acoustic guitarist, singer and songwriter whose reputation as a storyteller sets him apart from the folk mainstream.

With a career that spans rock, folk and country genres, EmmyLou Harris promises to create an evening of eclectic music. She is a 12-time Grammy winner and was inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame in 2008.
performer.perf_keywords: All I Intended to Be; Stumble Into Grace; Elite Hotel; Blue Kentucky Girl

performer.perf_description: The legendary indie rock band, which got its start in 1983, emerged in the 1980s with a series of lo-fi records and made a splash in the big leagues with its albums on TVT and Matador, including "Isolation Drills" and 'Half Smiles of the Decomposed." In 2014, after the release of "Cool Planet," the group disbanded, but in 2016, Pollard put together a new/old lineup; he brought in Bobby Bare Jr. on guitar, joined by previously ex-GBV guitarist (1997-2004) Doug Gillard, as well as drummer Kevin March (on his third go-round with the band) and new bassist Mark Shue. This lineup went on to record the album "Please Be Honest" later that year.

North Carolina's Southern Culture on the Skids -- guitarist singer Rick Miller, bassist/singer Mary Huff and drummer Dave Hartman -- has been releasing Southern-fried, rockabilly, swamp rock and boogie-woogie since 1985. The group celebrates the beauty of Waffle House waitresses, fried chicken (they often toss pieces to their audiences), Little Debbie oatmeal pies, double-wide trailers and demolition derbies through absurdist anthems of moonshine-laced hillbillydom.

Kenny Chesney has some career -- 20 albums in 22 years, 14 of them certified gold or higher; more than 40 Billboard top-10 country singles; six ACM awards (including four straight Entertainer of the Year trophies, 2005-08); host of No Shoes Radio on Sirius XM.
performer.perf_keywords: You Had Me From Hello; Fall in Love; When I Close My Eyes; She's Got It All; She Thinks My Tractor's Sexy; Entertainer of the Year; Academy of Country Music; Country Music Association; No Shoes Radio

performer.perf_description: With 10 multi-platinum albums and 16 top-30 hits, Foreigner carries on four decades later. They're responsible for some of rock and roll's most enduring anthems including "Juke Box Hero," "Feels Like The First Time," "Urgent," "Head Games," "Hot Blooded," "Cold As Ice," "Dirty White Boy," "Waiting For A Girl Like You," and the worldwide No. 1 hit "I Want To Know What Love Is."
performer.perf_keywords: arena rock; power-ballad; Urgent; Hot Blooded; I Want to Know What Love Is; Mick Jones; Ian McDonald; King Crimson; Lou Gramm

performer.perf_description: Connecticut's metal-hardcore band Hatebreed has been featured on MTV2's 'Headbangers Ball' show in addition to stints on such tours as Ozzfest and the Heavyweights of Hardcore since 1994. They have toured with Slayer, Slipknot and Mastodon and played at Ozzfest in 2006 alongside DragonForce, Lacuna Coil, Avenged Sevenfold, Disturbed and co-headliners System of a Down. They are currently touring to support their latest work, 'The Divinity of Purpose,' which was just released in late January 2013.
The Dark Star Orchestra is a Grateful Dead cover band with a unique approach. The group covers actual Dead set lists with the same arrangements from classic Dead performances.

Tricky has been for over a decade one of the seminal figures in electronic music. His collaborations with everyone from Massive Attack to Cypress Hill to PJ Harvey have put Tricky on the map as a force to be reckoned with in the genre. He's even dabbled in acting, with a supporting role in the 1997 film, 'The Fifth Element.'
Fueled by his departure from Sepultura, one of the biggest heavy metal bands in the world, and by the unsolved murder of his stepson, lead singer Max Cavalera has channeled his energy into this band.
performer.perf_keywords: Max Calvalera; Sepultura; Brazil; nu metal; Primitive; groove metal; heavy metal; unsolved murder; stepson; lead singer

performer.perf_description: With his invention, the Guit-steel (a standard six-string electric guitar and eight-string non-pedal steel, combined into one instrument) and top-notch vocals, Junior Brown is one of the most original and rewarding performers in country music.

John Flansburgh and John Linnell are the songwriting duo behind New York-based They Might Be Giants. Quirky pop songs and constant touring have made this group one of the most popular college rock bands of the past two decades.
performer.perf_keywords: John Flansburgh; John Linnell; New York; quirky; college rock band; popular

performer.perf_description: Mark Geary is a New York based Irish singer and songwriter.
Todd Snider's songs are often rich in wit, often hilarious, delivering clear critiques of society. Some are intimate ballads and some are good-natured romps celebrating life.

Originally called The Sensations and later The Dynamics, they emerged in the 1960s. Fans still buy tickets to the band now known as The Dramatics for their continuity, originality and purity in their voice and music.
performer.perf_keywords: originally The Sensations; emerged in the 1960s

performer.perf_description: Fifties teen idol and veteran performer Paul Anka has had numerous hits, including "Puppy Love," "Put Your Head on My Shoulder" and "You're Havin' My Baby." He's also an acclaimed songwriter who has penned hits for Frank Sinatra (the English version of "My Way"), Tom Jones, Michael Jackson and more, along with the theme to Johnny Carson's "Tonight Show."
performer.perf_keywords: Puppy Love; Put Your Head on My Shoulder; Frank Sinatra; fbtour; fbseven

performer.perf_description: The prolific David Olney infuses his live performances with an intensity that converts many new listeners into die-hard fans. Mr. Olney's intelligent compositions radiate that same intensity and have earned a place as one of the most respected singer-songwriters in the world today.

Ellis Paul was an architect of the Boston school of songwriting, an urbane, literate style that helped ignite the folk revival of the 1990s. His charismatic performance style has influenced a generation of folk-popsters and his songs can be heard on several movie and TV soundtracks.

Three Dog Night, formed in 1967 as Redwood, was one of the biggest bands in the world from the late 1960s to the mid-'70s. They racked up 12 gold albums and 21 consecutive Billboard hit singles, seven of which went gold. Three went to the top: "Mama Told Me Not to Come," "Joy to the World" (Billboard's No. 1 hit of 1971) and "Black and White." Other hits included "One," "Easy to Be Hard," "Out in the Country," "Liar," "Shambala," "An Old Fashioned Love Song," "Never Been to Spain" and "The Show Must Go On." Danny Hutton, one of the band's three original lead singers, and guitarist Michael Allsup, who joined very early on, carry the band's legacy as it closes in on five decades of performing.
performer.perf_keywords: fbseven; fbtour; distinctive; decades; Tennessee Symphony Orchestra; classic; hits

performer.perf_description: Aimee Mann first made her mark on the mainstream as the face of the '80s pop group Til Tuesday. But Mann really came into her own with her solo career, which boasts eight studio albums and an Academy Award nomination in 2000 for her song, "Save Me," from the film "Magnolia." Her lyric writing is lucid, with an ear for the rhythms of everyday expression.
performer.perf_keywords: Til Tuesday; Lost in Space; Save Me

performer.perf_description: ZZ Top, aka "That Little Ol' Band From Texas," lays undisputed claim to being the longest running major rock band with original personnel intact, and in 2004 the Texas trio was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame. Billy F. Gibbons, Dusty Hill and Frank Beard are still very much together after over 40 years of rock, blues and boogie on the road and in the studio. Their many hits include "Sharp Dressed Man," "La Grange" and "Legs."
performer.perf_keywords: Billy F. Gibbons;Dusty Hill;Frank Beard;Texas;TX;boogie;Sharp Dressed Man;La Grange;Legs

performer.perf_description: Grammy-winning singer-songwriter Melissa Manchester is most widely known as a pop recording artist, but she's also an accomplished musical theatre artist and has starred alongside Kelsey Grammer in the L.A. production of Stephen Sondheim's 'Sweeney Todd' and in the world premiere musical 'Hats!' in Chicago, for which she co-wrote several songs with Sarah Vaughn.
performer.perf_keywords: Grammy winner;When I Look Down That Road

performer.perf_description: Grammy-nominated guitarist/singer Robben Ford has distinguished himself in a variety of genres, from R&B to jazz-fusion. His first love has always been the blues, and with his new album, 'Blue Moon,' the eclectic musician is back to his beloved musical roots.

At the heart of Indigenous is guitarist/singer/songwriter Mato Nanji. Raised as a member of the Nakota Sioux Nation on the Yankton Indian Reservation in South Dakota, Mato first came to musical prominence when he formed Indigenous with his brother, sister and cousin. In 1998, they released their debut, 'Things We Do,' which received wide, mass reception and included the Top 10 smash hit 'Now That You're Gone.' After three successful albums, the siblings went their separate ways, and Mato forged ahead as the face of Indigenous releasing his Vanguard debut, 'Chasing The Sun.' The album's fiery blues prowess solidified Mato as one of blues-rock's most exciting talents. His most recent effort is 'Time is Coming.'
performer.perf_keywords: Things We Do;Now That You're Gone;Mato Nanji

performer.perf_description: One of the most successful folk/pop duos in recording history, Amy Ray and Emily Saliers have carved out an enduring career that is due largely to the fierce loyalty of their fans. After more than two decades, Ray and Saliers have played thousands of shows. They've operated within the music industry, without ever being a product of that industry, gaining the respect of their peers, not to mention an extremely loyal fan base.

Hailing from Chicago, Local H is a two-man band, featuring former drummer Ryan Harding and the guitarist and singer Scott Lucas. Originally categorized as grunge, the group survived the waning of that movement with what the New York Times in 2013 called "winning melodies and cathartic climaxes."
performer.perf_keywords: Chicago; Illinois; IL; Triple Fast Action; Brian St. Clair; Scott Lucas

performer.perf_description: In a career that spans five decades, 22 albums and three Grammy awards, multi-talented singer-songwriter-guitarist Tom Chapin has covered an incredible amount of creative ground. In addition to his work as a recording artist and concert performer, Chapin has acted on Broadway, as well as working extensively in television, radio and films.

Stars' music has been described as "beautiful, eloquent indie pop, characterized by lush instrumentation, nimble production and mixing, narrative lyrics, and soft but nuanced vocals." The Montreal-based quintet's style has evolved from an electronic-pop sound as heard on 'Nightsongs' to more rock-based instrumentation on their last two full-length albums.
performer.perf_keywords: Indie pop; Nightsongs; In Our Bedroom After the War; Set Yourself on Fire

performer.perf_description: Blessed with a great voice and great guitar and piano chops, Susan Werner is a multi-talented folk/pop singer and songwriter. Her eclectic and offbeat set of influences includes such names as Nanci Griffith, Jacques Brel, Thelonius Monk, Joni Mitchell, Sting and jazz diva Shirley Horn. But those influences only enhance the intimate, witty and virtuosic talents that have earned Werner a strong fan-base in clubs, concert halls and festivals worldwide.

Johnny Mathis is a legendary pop vocalist whose hits include "Chances Are" and "Too Much, Too Little, Too Late." A veteran of the music industry for nearly 60 years, Mathis won a Lifetime Achievement Grammy in 2003, has received multiple Grammy nominations, and has had three songs inducted into the Grammy Hall of Fame.
Long known for his songwriting genius, Rodney Crowell rose to country music prominence with 1988's 'Diamonds and Dirt,' an album that spawned five consecutive number one hits.
Reba McEntire was the single most successful female country vocalist of the' 80s and '90s, scoring a consistent stream of Top Ten singles and a total of 18 number-one singles.
In addition to being a singer, Brian McKnight is a songwriter, multi-talented musician, arranger and producer.

Former Nirvana drummer Dave Grohl started Foo Fighters as a one-man project in 1994 after Kurt Cobain's death, but it evolved into a full band, and within a year there was a self-titled album, as they announced themselves with the single "This Is a Call." Fast-forward and it's over two decades now, and Foo Fighters have had several hits such as "My Hero," "'Learning to Fly," "Everlong" and "DOA," and Grohl has become ubiquitous - fronting Foo Fighters, touring, performing as a guest at tribute and awards shows, directing the 2014 HBO series "Sonic Highways." And in September 2017, their ninth album, "Concrete and Gold," is being released, preceded by the single "Run." As of 2017, the lineup includes Grohl, original members bassist Nate Mendel and guitarist Pat Smear (of legendary L.A. punks the Germs; he was also Nirvana's touring rhythm guitarist), along with guitarist Chris Shiflett, drummer Taylor Hawkins and, as of 2017, keyboardist Rami Jaffee (formerly of The Wallflowers).
performer.perf_keywords: fbseven; fbtour; Nirvana;drummer;My Hero;Learning to Fly;fbseven;fbtour;My Hero, Learning to Fly

performer.perf_description: The Florida pop punk band New Found Glory formed in the summer of 1997 and is made up of vocalist Jordan Pundik, guitarist Chad Gilbert, bassist Ian Grushka and drummer Cyrus Bolooki. In all, they've recorded eight studio albums, one live album, two EPs and two cover albums.
performer.perf_keywords: Florida; pop-punk; Jordan Pundik; Chad Gilbert; Shai Hulud

performer.perf_description: Whether it is in films, on record or the stage, Sandra Bernhard brings her wit and personality to everything she does. With her band, The Rebellious Jezebels, she still has all the raucous energy of youth, bringing audiences to their feet.

One of the Original Kings of Comedy (which was both a smash national tour and hit film), D.L. Hughley is also known for his comic acting on NBC's short-lived 'Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip' and his ABC family sitcom, 'The Hughleys.' Hughley hosted his own shows Comedy Channel and BET, and has had numerous cable comedy specials and film appearances. His stand-up act is full of biting wit and politically charged humor.
performer.perf_keywords: Original Kings of Comedy; NBC; Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip; Hughleys

performer.perf_description: Todd Rundgren is one of rock's true visionaries, experimenting with various media to fashion his pop masterpieces. After starting in the Philadelphia-area band Nazz in the mid-'60s ("Open My Eyes"), Rundgren took off as a star in the early '70s, with many hits, including "Hello, It's Me," "I Saw the Light" and a for-note replication of The Beach Boys' "Good Vibrations." He also started the band Utopia in the late '70s, and had three critically acclaimed albums with them in the early '80s. In recent years, he has performed both on his own (that included a mid-'90s tour during the lounge craze, where he played tiki versions of his hits) and with Ringo Starr's All-Starr Band, but he returned to the limelight in 2017 with the politically charged album "White Knight"; it which featured the single "Mr. Tin Foil Hat," co-written with and sung by Steely Dan's Donald Fagen.
performer.perf_keywords: rock visionary; Hello, It's Me; I Saw the Light

performer.perf_description: Formed in Florida, Morbid Angel helped spearhead a death metal movement in the late '80s. After a performance and recording hiatus throughout a good portion of the 2000s, Morbid Angel returned to the stage and studio in 2010 and 2011, recording and releasing their eighth and latest studio album, 'Illud Divinum Insanus,' in June 2011. Decibel Magazine rated guitarist Trey Azagthoth as the number one "death metal guitarist ever".

From his time in the Doobie Brothers with songs like 'What a Fool Believes' and 'Taking It to the Streets' to his work with Steely Dan, Donna Summer, Kenny Loggins and Christopher Cross to his solo career, Michael McDonald has one of rock's more familiar voices.
Synonymous with dance music, energetic choreography and outrageous fun, the Village People had a string of hits in the heyday of disco, including 'YMCA,' 'Macho Man,' 'In the Navy' and 'Go West.'
performer.perf_keywords: gay; GLBT; queer; achetype; character; leatherman; Indian; chief; policeman; construction worker; soldier; cowboy; costume

performer.perf_description: Tom Rhodes has been on Comedy Central, MTV's 'Half-Hour Comedy Hour,' 'Comic Strip Live' or on Bill Mahr's 'Politically Correct.'
performer.perf_keywords: comedy;westgate;glendale;standup comedy;shows;west valley;Comedy Central;Half-Hour Comedy Hour;Comic Strip Live

performer.perf_description: Chicago blues legend and Rock and Roll Hall of Fame inductee Buddy Guy, now in his early 80s, has established himself as one of the music world's premiere guitar players, having influenced musicians since the late '50s and paved the way for many blues players to follow in his footsteps. The Louisiana-born Guy started off with a makeshift guitar, which was made from a two-string contraption attached to a piece of wood and secured with his mother's hairpins. He later moved to Chicago and got the recognition he needed from Muddy Waters, joining his band and becoming a house guitarist at Chess Records. The rest, as they say, is history. A major influence on rock titans like Jimi Hendrix, Eric Clapton, and Stevie Ray Vaughan, a pioneer of Chicago's fabled West Side sound, and a living link to the city's halcyon days of electric blues, Guy has received seven Grammy Awards, a 2015 Lifetime Achievement Grammy, 34 Blues Music Awards (the most any artist has received), the Billboard Magazine Century Award for distinguished artistic achievement, a Kennedy Center Honor, and the Presidential National Medal of Arts. Rolling Stone magazine ranked him No. 23 in its "100 Greatest Guitarists of All Time."
Award-winning jazz and neo-soul vocalist Ledisi is often described as sounding like Chaka Khan and Ella Fitzgerald with the energy of Tina Turner.

Clean can often mean not funny, but in the case of Brian Regan, it means streamlined, creative and enthusiastic. Audiences have been drawn to his howl-worthy comedy, which ranges from profound insights to silly exaggerations. Since his first appearance on "The Late Show With David Letterman" back in 1995, Regan has emerged as a viewer and audience favorite, typically making more than 80 stops a year to sold-out audiences across the country.
Har Mar Superstar is the stage name of Los Angeles-based musician Sean Tilmann.

William Royce "Boz" Scaggs got his start as a guitarist and occasional lead singer with the Steve Miller Band, appearing on the band's first two albums, 'Children of the Future' and 'Sailor.' Over his 30 plus year career, the Grammy-winning musician has racked up a catalog of hits including 'Lido Shuffle,' 'Look What You've Done To Me,' 'Miss Sun,' 'Jo Jo,' 'Heart Of Mine,' 'Lowdown,' 'Harbor Lights,' 'We're All Alone' and many others. He had performed on tour with Donald Fagen and Michael McDonald together as one band billed as The Dukes of September Rhythm Revue.

The inventor of the Sledge-o-matic, Leo Anthony Gallagher has taken the concept of food processing to new heights. The comic, former California gubernatorial candidate and presidential candidate will shower the audience with humor, pureed fruit salad and other food groups.
Led by singer-songwriter Scott Terry, Red Wanting Blue is a Columbus, Ohio band.

In the mid 1960's, The Grass Roots had a string of 14 Top 40 hits that kept the band on the charts nearly every week, including the songs 'Let's Live for Today,' 'Midnight Confessions,' 'Temptation Eyes' and 'Two Divided by Love.'
performer.perf_keywords: 1960's; Let's Live for Today; Midnight Confessions

performer.perf_description: Los Lonely Boys are the three Garza brothers: Henry on guitar, Jojo on bass and Ringo on drums. They play music drawn from diverse sources, blending the influences of Tex-Mex, country, blues and rock and roll pioneers like Richie Valens, Chuck Berry, and Fats Domino and such pop music giants as The Beatles,
Gardell was co-star with Melissa McCarthy of "Mike & Molly." the CBS sitcom that ran for six seasons. He has also been doing stand-up for years.
The Stolen are a high-energy pop-punk band. Based in Old Bridge, NJ, the band has developed a devout following touring up and down the East Coast.
Following a path trod by The Offspring, Blink-182 and others, the Canadian band Sum 41 features a mighty guitar section, some hardcore rock elements and a bit of hip-hop.

Jay Ungar and Molly Mason play American classics dating from the Civil War era to the present. The duo are best known for the piece "Ashokan Farewell," which served as the theme for the Ken Burns' award winning documentary series, "The Civil War."
performer.perf_keywords: American classics; Ashokan Farewell; Ken Burns; Civil War

performer.perf_description: The former Oasis frontman plays his first ever North American solo shows, performing material from his debut solo album ‘As You Were.'

Todd Barry was a Jury Award winner (for stand up comedy) in the 1998 U.S. Comedy Arts Festival in Aspen. He has been a guest on nearly every late night show you can think of, including appearances on 'The Late Show with David Letterman,' 'Late Night with Conan O'Brien' and NBC's 'Late Friday.' He was the exasperated boss in the Oscar winning movie 'The Wrestler,' and the bongo playing "Third Conchord" on 'Flight of the Conchords.'
The reclusive, anonymous experimental pop group, The Residents, has gained a rabid cult following over the years.
performer.perf_keywords: Avant-garde; post-punk; Snakefinger; Renaldo and the Loaf; visual arts; Shreveport; Louisiana; Philip Lithman; N. Senada; Captain Beefheart; cult; Penn Jillette; anonymous

performer.perf_description: Stephen Malkmus is the former lead singer of the now defunct indie-rock band Pavement.

"Songs of Experience" is the follow up to 2014's "Songs of Innocence." The two titles draw inspiration from a collection of poems, "Songs of Innocence and Experience," by the 18th century English mystic and poet William Blake.

'Showtime at the Apollo,' 'In Living Color' and 'The Tonight Show With Jay Leno' are where Ralph Harris first saw his career take off. However, he may be best known for his starring role in the ABC-TV sitcom 'On Our Own,' which aired during the network's popular TGIF block on Friday nights. He's also appeared on 'Seinfeld,' the films 'Dreamgirls' and 'Evan Almighty' and several cable TV specials.
performer.perf_keywords: In Living Color; Tonight Show; Last Comic Standing

performer.perf_description: A singer, songwriter and activist, John Flynn has shared the stage with Kris Kristofferson, Jack Elliot, Arlo Guthrie and Willie Nelson.

Suzanne Vega was the first major figure in the bumper crop of female singer/songwriters who rose to prominence during the late '80s and '90s. Her hushed, restrained folk-pop and highly literate lyrics laid the initial musical groundwork for what later became the trademark sound of Lilith Fair (a tour on which she was a regular). Moreover, her left-field hits 'Luka' and 'Tom's Diner' helped convince record companies that folk-styled singer/songwriters were not a thing of the past after all.

Since moving to Philadelphia from Boston, Katie Barbato has been cultivating her unique style of heartfelt, socially aware folk rock and growing her audience. She was a finalist in the 2015 International Songwriting Competition and also writes for television and film including the theme to the movie "Sugar" starring Shenae Grimes and Marshall Allman.

Out of jazz, indie rock and punk origins, her growing love of Americana finds singer-songwriter Laura Veirs exploring alt-country soundscapes with stunning and inspired results. The Hall of Flames is her new band featuring Annalisa Tornfelt (fiddle, vox), Eric Anderson (bass, keys, vox), Keeley Boyle (vox, percussion, balalaika) and Nelson Kempf (percussion, guitar, vox).

Stephen Stills' consummate, innovative musicianship has established him as an eminent solo performer & as the cornerstone of the supergroup Crosby, Stills & Nash. For four decades, Stephen Stills' music has spanned generations & cultural borders, entertaining millions of listeners throughout the world. His unique guitar style & phrasing has garnered Stills a well deserved spot among the best players in the world.

Calexico is a Mexican-flavored project of Giant Sand/Friends of Dean Martinez members Joey Burns (bass) and John Covertino (drums), who formed the group in 1996 in Tucson, Arizona, where they reside. They are currently touring to support their latest work, 'Algiers,' the band's seventh full-length album, named in tribute to the New Orleans neighborhood in which they recorded the album.
performer.perf_keywords: Giant Sand/Friends of Dean Martinez; Joey Burns; John Covertino; 1996; Tucson

performer.perf_description: Rock and Roll Hall of Fame rhythm section Stu Cook and Doug "Cosmo" Clifford from Creedence Clearwater Revival are joined by some new faces, including John Tristao, who was lead singer for the 60s band People; lead guitarist Kurt Griffey, who recorded or toured with CCR, Steppenwolf, Moody Blues, Lynyrd Skynyrd, Santana, Journey and Foreigner; and the L.A. musician Steve Gunner, who handles a multitude of instruments for CC Revisited. Without John Fogerty's nasal drawl, though, it's not the original CCR. But Fogerty has been at odds with Cook and Clifford for years.
performer.perf_keywords: music; top 40; John Fogerty; Stu Cook; Doug Clifford;

performer.perf_description: For more than 40 years, Bronx native Robert Klein has been a satiric commentator on life and the human situation. Klein has appeared in many notable films including "Hooper," "The Owl and the Pussycat," "Primary Colors," "People I Know," "Two Weeks Notice,' and "How to Lose a Guy in 10 Days." Klein regularly appears on talk-shows, making more than 100 appearances on 'The Tonight Show' and 'Late Show with David Letterman' alone.

Emerging from the Greenwich Village folk scene, Lucy Kaplansky made her mark singing and recording with such artists as Shawn Colvin and Suzanne Vega. Fusing folk-pop, rock and alt country into her own perfect blend, singer-songwriter Lucy Kaplansky gets to the heart of a song.
performer.perf_keywords: Singer/songwriter;folk-pop;alt-country;Tera Johnson;Greenwich Village;Shawn Colvin;Suzanne Vega;singer-songwriter;Cry, Cry Cry

performer.perf_description: Night Ranger is a hard-rock band whose star peaked in the mid-1980s. The band features ex-Ozzy Osbourne guitarist, Brad Gillis, and former Montrose keyboardist, Alan Fitzgerald, as well as Jack Blades, Jeff Watson, and Kelly Keagy.
Danielle Miraglia is a Boston-based singer/songwriter whose bluesy voice and guitar style are complimented by her music's rock verve, catchy melodies and eclectic song subjects.

Based in Portland, Oregon, The Decemberists have done some amazing work in the world of indie/folk and fusion rock over the years--blending hyper-literate lyrics about Irish folklore, life on the sea, Japanese legends and more with beautifully nuanced instrumentation. The quintet features Colin Meloy, Chris Funk, Jenny Conlee, Nate Query and John Moen.
performer.perf_keywords: Colin Meloy;Chris Funk;Jenny Conlee;Nate Query;John Moen;fusion rock

performer.perf_description: Port Chester, NY native Rachael Sage is a self-taught pianist, singer/songwriter and composer with several critically acclaimed albums. Between writing, composing her unique blend of classically tinged folk-pop and running her own record label (MPress Records), Sage performs 150-200 dates a year in venues across the country.

Nick Swardson is perhaps best known for his recurring role as Terry Bernadino in the TV series "Reno 911!," but he has also appeared on "The Tonight Show," "Comedy Central Presents" and many more, as well as the film "Bucky Larson: Born to be a Star," which he also wrote and produced.
performer.perf_keywords: comedy; comedian; Comedy Central; Opie and Anthony; Conan O'Brien; Tonight Show; laughs; humor

performer.perf_description: Kenny Loggins has logged (pardon the pun) many a memorable album since he started out at the age of 20. He has achieved worldwide superstardom, amassed a distinquished list of classic hits and received a star on the Walk of Fame. The Grammy winner's hits include 'This is It,' as well as several movie soundtracks including 'I'm Alright' from 'Caddyshack' and 'Danger Zone' from 'Top Gun.'
performer.perf_keywords: music; musician; singer; songwriter; Jim Messina; I'm Alright;

performer.perf_description: Born and raised in Canada, Bonneville picked up his signature sound as a teen in Boston. He brings together a gutsy fusion of guitar and harmonica in the country-blues vein.

Jazz keyboardist Jeff Lorber helped coin the term "New Adult Contemporary" (NAC) with his blend of funk, R&B, rock and eclectic jazz. He also played a significant role in developing the late '70s - early '80s R&B-jazz hybrid sound that later evolved into today's smooth jazz.
With more than a decade of innovative albums to their credit, the Newsboys have become a seminal influence in modern Christian music.

Built to Spill hails from the unlikely town of Boise, Idaho. In the 1990s the indie rockers found the middle ground between postmodern, pavement-style pop and the loose, spacious jamming of Neil Young. Singer/songwriter/guitarist Doug Martsch is at the core of the band. Band members Brett Nelson (bass), Scott Plouf (drums) Jim Roth (guitar) and Brett Netson (guitar) have all been musicians for two decades.

First achieving fame as lead singer and cofounder of October Project, Mary Fahl is an expressive and emotional singer songwriter. The hallmark of October Project's sound was Fahl's powerful vocals. Since disbanding, she has released several solo albums including a live recording and a re-working of Pink Floyd's "Dark Side Of The Moon."

The unique music of the Disco Biscuits is an energetic blend of electronic, techno, blues and rock. The Philadelphia, PA band consists of drummer Allen Aucoin, bass player Marc Brownstein, guitarist Jon Gutwillig and keyboard player Aron Magner. In 2007, the band co-headlined the D.U.M.B. (Disco-Umphrey's McGee-Biscuits) tour with Umphrey's McGee. They are currently in the midst of their 'Bisco Inferno Winter Edition' tour, in support of their most recent album, 'Otherwise Law Abiding Citizens.'

An alumnus of Jimmy Martin and J.D. Crowe's great '60s bluegrass bands, as well as the early-'70s lineup of The Country Gentlemen, Doyle Lawson set out on his own in the late '70s, carving out a specific niche as a bluegrass gospel performer. Quicksilver has had several great lineups, each of which combines flawless musicianship with a sweet, countrified take on "southern gospel" quartet vocals.

One of R&B music's most beloved and consistently popular vocal groups, The Whispers began their legendary and timeless career in 1963. They perfected their tight harmonies on the street corners in the Watts section of Los Angeles and in nightclubs in the San Francisco/Oakland Bay Area. The Whispers produced a string of hits over the next two decades and emerged as the leading romantic singers of their generation. These four men have been singing together as The Whispers for over three decades and they also are among the precious few stand-up vocal groups still actively recording and performing in the 2000s.
With a richly resonant voice & songs that represent the working class, Hal Ketchum has been called the poet laureate of country music.

Singer-songwriter Jimmy Buffett's easy-going, tropical folk-rock style has made him one of the biggest touring acts in the country. Best known for 'Margaritaville,' he also hit the charts with such songs as 'Fins' and 'Cheeseburger in Paradise.' In 2016, he and The Coral Reefer Band visit their Parrotheads around the country on the I Don't Know Tour.
performer.perf_keywords: music; musician; singer; songwriter; Margaritaville; Parrothead; party; Hawaiian shirt; rhythm; Cheeseburger in Paradise; flip flop; tropical

performer.perf_description: Lisa Lampanelli is known as comedy's 'Loveable Queen of Mean.' She's been seen on many a Comedy Central Roast (most notably Pamela Anderson's), in addition to her own comedy specials.

The Grammy-wonning Singer-songwriter, pianist and guitarist Marc Cohn became well-known in 1990 with the recording of his self-titled debut album, which yielded the hit 'Walking In Memphis,' 'Silver Thunderbird' and 'True Companion.'
Artie Fletcher, jokingly known as New York City's "Bad Boy of Comedy," has appeared on film, television radio and more.

The singer-guitarist, Albert Cummings, a Massachusetts native, played in Stevie Ray Vaughan's rhythm section. He has toured with B.B. King and Buddy Guy and keeps up a busy tour schedule that criss-crosses the U.S.

Tracy Morgan, who is perhaps best known for playing wild and unpredictable movie star Tracy Jordan in the Emmy Award-winning TV show, "30 Rock," is at heart a stand up comic who headlines across the country. TV audiences first met him in his role as "Hustleman" on the hit comedy series "Martin," but Morgan truly started to soar once he joined "Saturday Night Live" in 1996 where he appeared for seven seasons and created such memorable characters as "Astronaut Jones" and "Brian Fellows," to name just a few. He has also starred in his own comedy series, "The Tracy Morgan Show" for NBC and as the voice of "Spoonie Luv" on "Crank Yankers."
performer.perf_keywords: Tracy Jordan;30 Rock;Hustleman;Martin Lawrence;Saturday Night Live;Crank Yankers

performer.perf_description: Gilbert Gottfried has established himself as one of America's most popular comedic talents, having appeared in many television series, including a stint on 'Saturday Night Live,' and with roles in such films as 'Beverly Hills Cop II.'

Brian Setzer, former leader of the Stray Cats, fronts an intense 18-piece big band. Epitomized by their remake of Louis Prima's 'Jump, Jive an' Wail,' the Brian Setzer Orchestra mixes rockabilly and swing, and does so with such success that even when the craze had faded, the band has endured.

This former shoe salesman has become a successful stand-up comedian who has played clubs from Caroline's to The Laugh Factory and others nationwide. He's also risen to fame in movies, starring in such hits as "Ride Along" and "Get Hard."

Sloan is four distinct songwriting voices -- guitarists Patrick Pentland and Jay Ferguson, bassist Chris Murphy and drummer Andrew Scott -- that nonetheless form a cohesive collective. The band are long-time Toronto scenesters who will always call Halifax home.

performer.perf_description: Juan Estoban, who combines his two names into Juanes, combined the traditional elements of his native Colombian folk music into alternative musical setting and the results have earned him worldwide fame and three Latin Grammy Awards. Juanes uses the music of South America as a framework for his unique sound. Accordions, violins and cellos don't sound out of place, particularly when accompanied by a guitar, a Hammond organ and an insistent beat.

Multiple Grammy nominee and chart-topping country music star Dierks Bentley entertains audiences with his smooth, powerful vocals and engaging lyrics. His rowdy party anthem, 'Am I The Only One,' was the first smash hit off of Bentley's sixth studio album, 'Home,' and continues to be a crowd favorite.
Roots pop singer/songwriter Josh Rouse was born in Nebraska.

This celebrated five-member band delights audiences with thundering rhythms, mesmerizing melodies, and the wild wit of Ireland. Since their bust-out, big-screen debut in 'Titanic,' they have continued to broaden the musical horizons of Celtic music. Their contagious energy, carefree attitude and infectiously fun live performances have made them a must-see the world over.

The first frames of the "rockumentary" "Woodstock" contain the strains of Canned Heat's "Going Up The Country." That unofficial theme song of the legendary rock festival is the group's best-known hit, but they also scored with songs such as 'On The Road Again' and "Let's Work Together." The band's distinctive rock sound tinged with boogie, blues and country, has won them many fans and kept the working consistently over the past 40 years under the guidance of drummer and band leader Adolfo "Fito" de la Parra
The Los Angeles based group The Calling have made waves on the strength of their 2001 hit 'Wherever You Will Go.' The Calling's latest is 'Two.'

performer.perf_description: Tony Lucca is perhaps best known to American audiences as one of the finalists on season two of NBC's hit series, 'The Voice.' As a member of "Team Adam," his cover performancs of '99 Problems' and 'Yesterday' (performed as a duet with Adam Levine) were iTunes hits. No newbie to the business (he appeared on 'The Mickey Mouse Club' with Justin Timberlake and Christina Aguilera), he has appeared on the TV show 'Parenthood' (as himself, performing his song, 'Like Love') and performed on 'Last Call With Carson Daly.'
Acid Mothers Temple hails from Nagoya in the Central region of Japan. The band describes itself as a "freak-out group for the 21st century."
The Matches are a pop/punk/alternative/rock band from Oakland, California. The band features Shawn Harris (vox/guitar), Matt Whalen (drums), Justin San Souci (bass/vox) and Jon Devoto (guitar/vox).

performer.perf_description: His fans know him as the leader of the beloved New England pop-rock crew the Push Stars, and industry folks know him as a go-to songwriter: Chris Trapper's songs have seen countless movies and TV shows, and have been covered by everyone from matchbox twenty frontman Rob Thomas to girl-rockers Antigone Rising. His words and music can best be described as an interesting blend of 1950s pop, 1990s rock and old-timey jazz with the ever-present understory of Chris' distinctive "baritenor." It's intricate power-pop with a compelling knack for telling everyday stories.

Originally formed in 1985 as a Black Flag-influenced hardcore punk band called Virulence, Fu Manchu has since become one of hard rock's most celebrated names. The band released its first single 'Kept Between Trees' in 1990 and in the years following, helped give rise to a celebrated style of heavy music tagged "stoner rock."
Neko Case sings punk-fueled alternative country. Case won a steadily growing cult audience for her smoky, sophisticated vocals and the downcast beauty of her music.
EELS is the brainchild of vocalist, guitarist and chief songwriter E (Mark Oliver Everett).
Vic has been described as "the working man's answer to comedy" with his discourse on married life, children and snippets of his Italian-American heritage.

Schultz has sold more than 1.3 million albums and enjoyed success on the Mainstream Adult Contemporary chart, scoring 10 No. 1 singles to date. He also landed the top spot on Billboard magazine's Christian Adult Contemporary Songwriter list and has been featured on '48 Hours' and 'Extreme Makeover: Home Edition.' His 2005 release, 'Mark Schultz Live...A Night of Stories & Songs,' was certified Platinum by the R.I.A.A. and earned Schultz his first GMA Dove Award.

Carlos Mencia is a multiple award-winning comic, including a Cable ACE award for Best Stand-up Comedy Special. He made a name for himself with repeat appearances on Comedy Central and the award-winning special, which appeared on HBO in 2002. His Comedy Central series "Mind of Mencia" ran on Comedy Central from 2005 to 2008.

Minus the Bear is an indie rock group formed in Seattle in 2001. Their fifth full-length studio album, 'Infinity Overhead' was released in August 2012. Their sixth, "Voids," was released in the spring of 2017.
The foursome called The Used has been noted for their resemblance to such bands as Glassjaw, The Deftones, Jimmy Eat World and Finch.

Jake Shimabukuro, the undisputed master of Hawaii's most classic instrument, the ukulele, is on his way to becoming a household name with over 12 million performance views on YouTube. The ukulele virtuoso, featured in the documentary film "Mighty Uke," is also a studio and touring favorite of the likes of Ziggy Marley, Bela Fleck and Jimmy Buffett. His repertoire runs from The Beatles' "While My Guitar Gently Weeps" (penned by ukelele aficionado George Harrison) to Queen's "Bohemian Rhapsody" to Schubert's "Ave Maria" to Leonard Cohen's "Hallelujah."
Rosetta is a Philadelphia-based ambient metal quartet.

Dennis DeYoung is the former keyboardist and founding member of Styx. In addition to four solo albums, DeYoung has performed outside of the rock arena in the musical 'Jesus Christ Superstar' and has written songs for a musical version of 'The Hunchback of Notre Dame.'

It was only a matter of time before the bold sound of party rock would make a triumphant return. First, there was Van Halen and Kiss and then Poison and Twisted Sister. Now meet Andrew W.K. (aka Wilkes-Krier), the great new hope for the third millennium. He might be yanking our legs, but the gag is so deadpan it barely registers as parody.

Check out the nastiest machines in motorsports when Monster Jam rolls into town. The event brings 10,000 pound, 1,500 horsepower Hot Rod Monster Trucks to do battle in a "Roundy round" racing format. Led by the legendary Grave Digger and other fan favorites, this class of metal-munching monster trucks is ready to tear up the track. These trucks employ the latest technology to provide a spectacle of rock and roar that's unequalled anywhere in the motor sports industry.

The songs of Tom Brosseau, a North Dakota native, touch on, in Brosseau's words, "abandoned buildings, new love, the praireland, being haunted, roaming around, and being thrilled and killed." It is the work of a master storyteller, who draws from such diverse influences as Marty Robbins, Led Zeppelin, Nick Drake, and Billie Holiday.
Rasputina is a cello-based band fascinated with 19th-century romanticism and the use of fantasy as a means of expression.

'Chippendales: The Show' is a tastefully choreographed show for an all-female audience.

Comedian Ron "Tater Salad" White, perhaps best known as the cigar-smoking, scotch-drinking funnyman from the "Blue Collar Comedy" phenomenon, has emerged as a star in his own right and had been one of the top grossing comedians on tour in the U.S. He also can boast of two Grammy nominations, a gold record, three of the highest rated specials in Comedy Central history, a New York Times bestselling book, and CD and DVD sales of over 10 million units.
When Michael Blackson takes the stage clad in the finest dashikis the Motherland has to offer, "The African King of Comedy" is born. Blackson appeared in Ice Cube's 2000 stoner comedy "Next Friday."
This all girl band plays party music with groovy techno, pop funk, classic rock with hip hop influences.

The B-52s (Fred Schneider, Kate Pierson, Keith Strickland and Cindy Wilson), perhaps best known for their hit song 'Love Shack,' formed in Athens, GA back in the late '70s and named themselves after Southern slang for a particular beehive hairdo that resembled the nose of an aircraft. Their first single 'Rock Lobster,' recorded in 1978, was an underground success, and on the strength of their energetic, post-punk live shows at such legendary venues as CBGB in New York City and Max's Kansas City, their self-titled debut sold more than 500,000 copies. Now, more than 30 years and 20 million albums sold later, the group is still one of the most beloved party bands in existence. The touring band includes members Sterling Campbell, Paul Gordon and Tracy Wormworth.

The Kills are the British guitar player Jamie Hince and American singer Alison Mosshart. These two have been making music since 2002. They are releasing a new album, "Ash & Ice," in 2016, three years after Hince injured his hand so badly he required a tendon transplant and lost the use of his middle finger. He has had to relearn the guitar.

performer.perf_description: Former star of NBC's 'The Tonight Show With Jay Leno,' this famous host has created his own unique "late-night style" with humor, talk and entertainment. One of the country's premier comedians, Leno is a passionate live performer who loves his audiences.

Austin-based guitarist and singer Chris Duarte plays a rhythmic style of Texas blues-rock that draws on elements of jazz, blues and rock 'n' roll. His sound has often been compared with Johnny Winter and the late Stevie Ray Vaughn.

Punk rock veterans Street Dogs are touring in support of their critically acclaimed new album, 'State of Grace.' The Boston raised band have made a name for themselves over the years with rowdy and participatory live shows that are packed with enough fist pumping and frenzied pit action to leave fans coming back for more. Singer Mike McColgan, who was the original founding singer of the Dropkick Murphys and former Boston firefighter, draws on a wealth of life experiences and observations to inspire his riveting vocal performances, adding a touch of sincere urgency to the non-stop fist-a-cuffs of teeth-gnashing punk rock that the band is known for.

David Ford is a singer/songwriter from the U.K.

Singer-songwriter Tyrone Wells blends pop, soul and rock. Though he has never scored an out-and-out hit, his music has been featured in movies and television and he tours constantly from coast to coast.
Louisiana-born Marc Broussard combines traditional soul, R&B and hook laden rock into his Bayou-influenced sound.

"Everyone needs to be risking something," says Seattle-based alt-country/folk singer-songwriter Brandi Carlile. "The Firewatcher's Daughter," her stunning 2015 release - her first for artist-friendly indie label ATO. marked a triumphant return after a three-year recording hiatus, and her strongest, most rock & roll album to date. Since her heralded, genre-defying 2005 Columbia debut, Carlile and her collaborators, Tim and Phil Hanseroth, aka The Twins, have always offered listeners both control and abandon, often within a single song. Her best-known tunes, 2007's "The Story" and 2012's "That Wasn't Me," are dynamic journeys in themselves, encompassing myriad emotions and varied stylistic touches.
This Swedish band features vocalist Joacim Cans, guitarists Oscar Dronjak and Stefan Elmgren, drummer Anders Johansson and bassist Magnus Rosen.
Madeleine Peyroux sings a hypnotic blend of jazz, folk, country and blues.

Marah is an American country-rock band that formed in Philadelphia in 1993. They got a huge boost from their association with Bruce Springsteen in the early 2000s. Their 2000 album "Kids in Philly" drew comparisons to Bruce; he added backing vocals to "Float Away" on the 2002 album "Float Away With the Friday Night Gods"; he's has Marah open for him several times in concert; and he's been known to pop up every so often at one of their shows. The band, which has gone through several lineup changes over the years, has released 11 albums, two EPs and a DVD.
performer.perf_keywords: float away with the Friday Night Gods

performer.perf_description: Uncle Bonsai, a folk pop trio, performs funny original songs. Laced with their trademark acerbic themes, their songs are frank vignettes about beauty, TV, the misery of relationships sung in exquisite three-part harmonies.

The "Yanni 25 - Live At The Acropolis Anniversary Concert Tour" celebrates the self-taught musician with the self-imposed charge to 'take life's experiences and translate them to music.' Yanni, born Yanni Chryssomalis, has attracted a loyal following with his elaborate orchestrations and intricate keyboard compositions.

The Kansas City rapper born Aaron Dontez Yates has recorded with such legends as 2Pac, Eminem and Kendrick Lamar. His work has also been featured on the soundtracks for 'Gang Related' and 'Thicker Than Water.' His 15th album, "Special Effects," reached No. 4 on the Billboard album chart.

Dr. Dog is an indie, psychedelic rock band from the greater West Philadelphia area. Band members play two guitars, bass, drums, keyboard and three part harmonies. Philadelphia Weekly has described the band's music as a blend of "a little folk, blues, indie rock, soul, bluegrass and a whole lot of down-home harmonizing. They channel The Band one moment, the Beach Boys another, and Pavement the next."

performer.perf_name: The Sound of Music: National Tour
performer.perf_description: This brand new production of "The Sound of Music" is directed by three-time Tony Award winner Jack O'Brien. Power Trip is a hardcore metal band from Dallas, Texas.
This very unique band combines many different music styles into its show such as rock, reggae, acoustic and bluegrass.

The Melvins coalesced as a band in 1983 in Montesano, Washington, at the base of the Olympic Peninsula. They influenced the sludge and drone subgenres, including Nirvana, and were themselves influenced by Black Flag's mix of punk and metal on their album "My War," and other slow punk acts like Swans, Flipper and Wipers.

performer.perf_description: Buckethead is one of the more bizarre and enigmatic figures to be found in American underground and experimental music. He is a virtuoso on the electric guitar, True to his name, Buckethead (born Brian Carroll) wears an inverted KFC bucket on his head along with a full-face white mask. He produces elaborate stage shows, innovative musicianship, rapid-fire riffing, near-robotic fretwork and idiosyncratic ramblings that combine elements of Yngwie Malmsteen, Adrian Belew, avant-improv artist John Zorn and more.

Proficient on guitar, violin, mandolin and banjo, Bromberg's music contains elements of folk, blues, bluegrass and rock. Comedy and lengthy narrative stories are often inserted between choruses.

The Chester County Concert Band proudly invites you "All Aboard!" on Sunday, November 5 at 2:30 at Fugett Middle School in West Chester. Founded in 1981 and conducted by David W. Reif, the band will keep you "on track" with all kinds of fun train-related music to entertain audience members of all ages. Included will be The Great Locomotive Chase, Chattanooga Choo-Choo, Night Journey, Take the A Train, I've Been Working on the Railroad, Wabash Cannonball and many more favorites. We will also have a guest trumpet soloist - Mr. Jean-Christophe Dobrzelewski a trumpet professor from West Chester University. He will be performing three exciting pieces with the band. The band will be giving their portion of their 50/50 raffle to the West Chester Railroad. A representative will be on hand to accept the donation.
Chris Kasper is a singer/songwriter/guitarist from Morgantown, West Virginia, who now calls Philadelphia home.

performer.perf_name: The World Famous Glenn Miller Orchestra
performer.perf_description: The legendary Glenn Miller Orchestra will get your toes a tappin' with songs like 'Moonlight Serenade,' 'In the Mood' and 'Don't Sit Under the Apple Tree.' They may be from an era gone by, but they still get under your skin. The present Glenn Miller Orchestra was formed in 1956 and has been touring consistently since, playing an average of 300 live dates a year all around the world. The 18-member band continues to play many of the original Miller arrangements.

England's the Darkness centers around guitarist and vocalist Justin Hawkins, his brother Dan Hawkins, bassist Frankie Poullain and drummer Ed Graham. Exploding onto Britain's rock scene in 2002, the Darkness single-handedly resurrected the rather unfashionable sounds and attitudes of late-‘70s hard rock for an unsuspecting generation.

Since 1984 Primus has been pushing the boundaries of punk/rock/metal music just as artists like Frank Zappa and Pink Floyd did before them. In 2011 they released "Green Naugahyde" which was their first in 11 years. Currently composed of bassist/vocalist Les Claypool, guitarist Larry "Ler" LaLonde and drummer Tim Alexander, Primus and the Chocolate Factory will hit the road with a two-set "evening with" show in support of their new record, due in October. A tribute to the 1971 movie "Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory", the new album will be the band's eighth studio record and, the first from the band's classic line-up since 1995.
Piney Blues is a bluegrass quartet who are Albert Music Hall regulars.
Anna Egge is a singer/songwriter from Saskatchewan, Canada.
Dirty Heads is a five-piece reggae-rock band from Huntington Beach, California.

performer.perf_description: The Weepies is the duo of singer-songwriters Steve Tannen and Deb Talan. The couple met around 2006, teamed up professionally, married, had three children and sold a million records.

Matt Costa almost became a pro skater, but an accident shattered his leg. During his recovery, Matt directed his energy, passion and talent toward music. Matt's homemade demo found its way into the hands of No Doubt guitarist Tom Dumont. Costa made such an impression that Dumont produced a self-titled 5 song EP that woul lead to a full-length, 'Songs We Sing.'

performer.perf_description: At their high point through the early '90s, the sound of Scotland's Trashcan Sinatras proudly reclaimed the joyous pop sound of such early '80s bands as the Bluebells, Orange Juice and Aztec Camera.

Ray LaMontagne is an American singer-songwriter. It has been said that he decided to quit his job at a shoe factory and start a music career after hearing a Stephen Stills song on the radio. Since then he has toured internationally and released 4 studio albums. His hit song 'Trouble,' as well as many others have been featured in a variety of films and television shows.

Strangefolk frontman Reid Genauer formed Assembly of Dust in 2002 while enrolled in the MBA program at Cornell University. The band has played at Bonnaroo and many other music festivals across the land. The group's 2016 album "Sun Shot" is, according to the band, "one part Singer-Songwriter, one part Alt- Country and one part Rock and Roll," with lyrics by Genauer.

performer.perf_description: The Hasidic singer-sonwriter Matisyahu stands out like no other. This lyricist, MC and beatboxer explores traditional Jewish themes and spirituality by mixing in ever-more exploratory journeys into reggae, rock and hip-hop beatboxing sounds. His second album, "Youth" was nominated for a Grammy and his third, "Light" reached the top of the reggae charts. His latest release, "Undercurrent," is a more personal, musically thematic eight song cycle.
Combining countless influences, but focusing on ska, punk and reggae, Streetlight Manifesto, a seven-piece band out of New Jersey, has established themselves over the years as ska-punk stawarts.
A 600 sq. ft. Pickin' Shed is on the grounds for musicians to informally meet and play.
Punchline is a four-piece pop-punk band from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania.

Aaron Lewis is the lead vocalist and founding member of Staind. His own solo album, Town Line,' allowed him to venture into country music. His first full-length solo release, "The Road," was released in 2012. In 2013 he headlined the Jagermeister Country Tour, debuted on the Grand Ole Opry and was nominated for four Sportsman Choice Awards. He released his latest album, "Sinner," in the fall of 2016, featuring a cameo from Willie Nelson on the title song, as well as a cover of Chris Stapleton's "Whiskey and You."
Bassist Pete Donnelly is a founding member of The Figgs. His current musical projects include performing with Soul Asylum as well as the Terry Adams Rock and Roll quartet (NRBQ).

Harry Connick Jr. became a household name thanks to his latter-day crooning on the soundtrack to "When Harry Met Sally." The New Orleans native, considered by some to be the heir-apparent to Frank Sinatra, has explored many facets of pop and jazz. But it's with his big band that he has earned kudos for his feisty bandleading and his thoughtful, commercially-viable arrangements. Now, as one of the judges on "American Idol," the popularity of the Grammy-winning artist continues to soar.
Hawthorne Heights is a Dayton, Ohio, metal band formed in the days when emo was THE sound. They have played Warped Tour several times in recent years.

With 40 plus years of entertainment experience and as a Headliner at The Superstar Theater at the Resorts Hotel & Casino in Atlantic City, Jimmy Mazz truly understands how to entertain an audience. His versatility and song selection are key. Combined with his ability to sound like the original artist in many cases, his voice is rich and elegant. His energetic visual performance and relaxed antics really entertain. With his intriguing musical choices, amusing trivia, candid humor, and great charisma, Jimmy Mazz shows are truly memorable. Jimmy's delivery of emotion may have you laughing and crying in the same song. Jimmy's very warm and genuine personality makes every show personal and appealing to folks of all ages. Jimmy helps make any function a complete success. He relates to and interacts with his audience without being intrusive, yet he commands their attention from start to finish.
Lissie Maurus has signed record deals with Sony U.K.; Columbia, also in the U.K. and Fat Possum in the U.S. Her most recent album, "My Wild West," is out on her own label.

Kix was founded in 1978 in Hagerstown, Maryland, as The Shooze, then changed its name to The Generators before eventually settling on Kix. The band's pop-metal stylings drew inspiration from bubblegum pop and new wave as well as hard rock.

A founding member of Creedence Clearwater Revival, John Fogerty's solo releases "Centerfield" and "Blue Moon Swamp" have earned him acclaim and praise from fans around the world. In addition, Fogerty and his #1 recording "Centerfield" were honored during the 2010 National Baseball Hall of Fame Induction Ceremonies--the first time the National Baseball Hall of Fame has immortalized a musician or song as part of the annual ceremonies. He's also called the "Father of the Flannel Shirt."
performer.perf_keywords: Creedence Clearwater Revival; swamp rock; The Golliwogs; roots rock; Doug Clifford; Stu Cook; Tom Fogerty; The Blue Ridge Rangers

performer.perf_description: With several No. 1 radio singles, many Grammy nominations and even more Dove Awards, Chris Tomlin is among the most well-known artists in contemporary Christian music today. Credited with such venerable church choruses as 'How Great is Our God,' 'Forever,' 'We Fall Down' and 'The Wonderful Cross,' Chris Tomlin is considered one of this era's top songwriters for the church with five songs in CCLI's Top 60 and four more in the service's Top 500. With millions singing his songs weekly, Chris is recognized as a pivotal voice of today's modern expression of Christian worship.
Machinedrum is the musical project of Brooklyn-based electronic musician Travis Stewart.
Blue October is a five-piece rock band that was formed in 1995 by brothers Justin and Jeremy Furstenfeld along with multi-instrumentalist, Ryan Delahoussaye.

Both with Peter, Paul & Mary and as a soloist, singer-songwriter Peter Yarrow is recognized for using music to convey a message of humanity and caring. For over five decades, he has devoted his gift for songwriting and organizing to environmental and social justice movements.

Trampled by Turtles is an original, non-traditional bluegrass band from Duluth, MN. Their energetic live performances and well-received albums, including 'Songs From a Ghost Town' and 'Blue Sky and the Devil,' have gained them a large and loyal fan base throughout the Midwest and beyond. They are currently in the midst of their winter tour to support their most recent album, 'Stars and Satellites,' and at each show they'll be auctioning off a special gift package that includes tickets, signed memorabilia and more. Proceeds from the auction will benefit WhyHunger.
performer.perf_keywords: Songs From a Ghost Town; Blue Sky and the Devil

performer.perf_description: Beatlemania Now is comprised of four seasoned musicians who capture the spirit, look and sound of the Beatles in 35 renditions of the songs that you love. The group uses authentic costumes and instruments dating back to the Beatles era. The show brings the audience through a five-year period from 1964 to 1969. They start off wearing the suits from the Beatles appearance on the Ed Sullivan Show and perform the hits of that particular era and then move through Sgt. Pepper to Abbey Road.
performer.perf_keywords: The Beatles; covers; tribute show; authentic costumes; authentic instruments; Ed Sullivan Show; 1964-1969; Abbey Road

performer.perf_description: Multi-instrumentalist Uli Jon Roth was the lead guitarist for Scorpions from 1973 to 1978. Roth is also a prolific orchestral composer, writer and poet; as well as the inventor of the 6-octave "Sky Guitar," whose sound is the cornerstone of his band Electric Sun.

Helmet rose to fame on the strength of its 1992 debut, 'Meantime,' plus hits with the soundtrack cuts 'Just Another Victim' (from 'Judgment Night') and 'Milquetoast' (from the soundtrack to 'The Crow'). Frontman Page Hamilton and his relatively new lineup bring to the stage the same brand of "thinking person's heavy metal" that earned the band their place in head-bangers' collections long ago.
performer.perf_keywords: Meantime; 1990s; 90s; Just Another Victim; Judgment Night; Milquetoast; The Crow; Page Hamilton

performer.perf_description: Based in Pittsburgh, Black Moth Super Rainbow has been around since 2002 and features an all analog sound, something like happy fuzzy pop and extremely psychedelic Krautrock. The songs are written from a folk perspective so the music never feels overly electronic and never sterile. Described as "dark bubblegum freakout" the band's sound is "refreshingly new and mysteriously futuristic," and features "tantalizing ear candy...analogue high speed chases, swirling synths crashing into each other and vocoded vocals."

The Chapin Sisters consists of Abigail and Lily Chapin (daughters of Tom, nieces of '70s legend Harry) and Jessica Craven (daughter of horror director Wes, stepdaughter of Tom), whose musical style blends traditional folk harmonies with an Indie rock/Emo moodiness (think Crosby Stills and Nash meets Cat Power.) Their lo-fi originals are gorgeous and melancholy, while their covers of Britney Spears' 'Toxic' and The Cure's 'Boys Don't Cry' are haunting and strangely unfamiliar.

Get The Led Out, also known as "GTLO" and "The American Led Zeppelin," is a group of professional rock musicians dedicated to re-creating the recorded music of Led Zeppelin as authentically as possible.
Discover what goes on behind the scenes at the aquarium while touring the building. Pre-registration and sneakers are required.
Pissed Jeans is a "noise rock" foursome from Allentown.
The Sword is a metal band from Austin, TX, whose influences include Black Sabbath, Iron Maiden and Prong.

No stranger to television, Chicago native Sebastian Maniscalco catapulted into the national spotlight with a 20-city tour for his one-hour Comedy Central DVD Special 'Sebastian Live!' On 'The Tonight Show with Jay Leno,' Sebastian appeared as the unforgettable style correspondent providing hilarious grooming advice to unsuspecting airline passengers and churchgoers.
Emmure is a hardcore rock band from Connecticut.

performer.perf_name: Classic Albums Live: Pink Floyd's The Wall
performer.perf_description: Classic Albums Live is a rock show in which some of the best musicians recreate, live and with exact precision, definitive albums.

Barenaked Ladies were founded in 1988 by singer-guitarists Steven Page and Ed Robertson. The group has a reputation as one of the best live acts out there with their genre-hopping style. The group features Robertson with Jim Creegan, Tyler Stewart and Kevin Hearn.
performer.perf_keywords: Steven Page; Ed Robertson; One Week; Toronto; Barenaked Ladies Are Me

performer.perf_description: Since 1996 and the release of their debut album, "Apocalyptica Plays Metallica by Four Cellos," Apocalyptica -- graduates of the prestigious Sibelius Academy in Finland -- have been developing a style that is tough to put a name to... 'Heavy Cello Mayhem'? 'Rock'n' Resin'?! ... The possibilities are vast, but whatever the latest tag, the fact remains that never before had a group of classically-trained cellists, metal fans to a man, attempted to fuse together the seemingly disparate worlds of classical music & hard rock ...of Prokofiev & Pantera ... Shostakovich & Slayer ... to seek out the middle ground between the mosh pit & the orchestra pit, the dinner jacket & the denim jacket, whilst being 100 percent respectful to both camps.
performer.perf_keywords: Metallica; Cello; Helsinki; Finland; neo-classical metal; Hevein; Lahti Symphony Orchestra; Sibelius Academy; Faith No More; Sepultura; Pantera; Greenpeace; chamber music; cello rock

performer.perf_description: The 1910 Fruitgum Company virtually exploded onto the national charts back in 1968 with the hits 'Simon Says' and '1-2-3 Red Light.'
Circa Survive is a five-piece Philadelphia band that was founded in 2004.

Formed in 1997, Flogging Molly combines Celtic music with punk rock to form what they call "a Guinness soaked musical body blow." They've released five albums, the latest being "Speed of darkness" in 2011. In time for St. Patrick's Day 2016, they released their first recording in five years, the single "The Hand of John L. Sullivan."
Blackfoot is considered one of the most influential Southern rock bands of all time.
Michael Che has been featured in the NY Times, the NY Comedy Festival, and was selected as one of Comedy Central's "Comics To Watch" in 2011.

McMahon is a singer, songwriter and pianist who fronted the alternative pop band Something Corporate and later Jack's Mannequin. His most recent album, "Zombies on Broadway," was No. 1 on Amazon's Alternative Rock chart in early 2017 without a breakout hit single, "Fire Escape."

performer.perf_name: Ringo Starr & His All Starr Band
performer.perf_description: The legendary drummer of The Beatles leads this rock supergroup with shifting personnel. The current lineup includes Todd Rundgren, Steve Lukather, Gregg Rolie, Richard Page, Warren Ham and Gregg Bissonette.

Originally from the UK, Callaghan moved to the USA in 2010 to tour and record with Grammy-nominated US artist Shawn Mullins. Since then she's become a headliner in multiple cities across the US and UK. Playing piano and guitar Callaghan delivers a stunning vocal which earns frequent comparisons with artists like Sarah McLachlan and Emmylou Harris. Her songwriting chronicles the stories, experiences and emotions which are part of everyone's lives. On tour in support of her new EP, Skin on Skin.

The Yardbirds of the 1960s gave us three of the great rock guitarists: Eric Clapton, Jeff Beck and Jimmy Page. They created hard rock out of standard twelve-bar blues, doubling the tempos and whacking the amps up to ten. The Yardbirds expanded the range of the electric guitar, experimenting with feedback, sustain and fuzztone. They were a bridge between the tributary white R&B of early-sixties London and the pastures of fuzz-toned psychedelia and power-chorded heavy metal that came later. Jim McCarty, the one remaining original member, fronts a new generation of the band. The lineup he put together in 2015 includes guitarist Johnny A, bassist Kenny Aaronson, singer/harpist/percussionist Myke Scavone and guitarist/singer John Idan.
performer.perf_keywords: Eric Clapton; Jeff Beck; Jimmy Page; feedback; electric guitar; fuzztone; Chris Dreja; Jim McCarty; new generation

performer.perf_description: Tom Heyman is a country singer, songwriter.

LA singer/songwriter Jackson Browne is known for such hits as "Running on Empty," "Doctor My Eyes," "The Pretender" and more. His introspective, literate lyrics have crossed personal and political borders over the years, but throughout his 40-plus years in the music business, Browne's been a touchstone for those among his fanbase.
performer.perf_keywords: Running on Empty;Stay;Doctor My Eyes;country rock;soft rock

performer.perf_description: Formed in 1971, this group scored multiple hits such as "Three Times a Lady," (released when Lionel Richie was frontman,) and "Nightshift."
performer.perf_keywords: Lionel Richie; Three Times a Lady; Nightshift; Brick House

performer.perf_description: From Gibsonton, FL, the death metal band Obituary formed in 1984, broke up in 1997, reunited in 2003 and continues to survive. While there have been several lineup changed through the years, the core of John Tardy (vocals), brother Donald Tardy (drums) and Trevor Peres (rhythm guitar) has remained the same. They have 10 albums to date, the latest being a self-titled 2017 effort.
performer.perf_keywords: Gibsonton; death metal; John Tardy; Ralph Santolla; Frank Watkins, Donald Tardy; Trevor Peres

performer.perf_description: The world has never "Lost That Lovin' Feelin'" for the distinctive sound of Bobby Hatfield and Bill Medley, The Righteous Brothers. Now performing with singer Bucky Heard, Bill Medley continues the phenomenon of "blue-eyed soul" that produced such hits as 'Unchained Melody' and '(You Are My) Soul And Inspiration.'
Hot Snakes was an American rock band led by Rick Froberg and John Reis, formed in 1999 in San Diego, California and disbanded in 2005.
Formed in 2008, Pond are an Australian rock band featuring Joseph Ryan, Nick Allbrook and Jay Watson.
Ring of Combat features bouts between the best Mixed Martial Artists in the world. Mixed Martial Arts is a combination of traditional karate, kickboxing and submission grappling (ground fighting).

Outspoken, precocious, lovable Junie B. Jones stars in a colorful, funny, fast-paced musical about new friends, new glasses, sugar cookies, the annual kickball tournament, and other various first-grade angst-ridden situations. Follow her adventures as she writes down the story of her life in her "Top-Secret Personal Beeswax Journal." This new musical is based on four volumes in Barbara Park's Junie B. Jones series of books.
Crack the Sky is a prog-rock band that formed in the '70s.

My Brightest Diamond is a chamber pop band spearheaded by singer/songwriter Shara Worden. After earning an opera degree at the University of North Texas, she moved to New York City to simultaneously continue her opera studies and pursue her songwriting ambitions, releasing two albums with her band Awry. After the breakup of Awry, Shara assembled a coterie of musicians to accompany her with bass and drums, strings, wine glasses and wind chimes, and thus the sound of My Brightest Diamond was formed. Shara's Mancini-esque string arrangements laced with dramatic guitars and punk rock drums define the Diamond sound. On stage she channels the vocal theatrics of Jeff Buckley, the soulful seductiveness of Nina Simone, and the gothic pop of Portishead. The band's second album is 'A Thousand Shark's Teeth,' released on Asthmatic Kitty Records.
performer.perf_keywords: Shara Worden; Epiphone; accordion; organ; Mancini; string; arrangement; Jeff Buckley; Nina Simone; gothic pop; Portishead; A Thousand Shark's Teeth; Asthmatic Kitty Records

performer.perf_description: Nashville native Gabe Dixon was greatly influenced by the heritage that surrounded him and his music is more than simple rock tunes; they're fused with elements of blues and alt-pop sounds. He released his sophomore solo album, "Turns To Gold," in April 2016 on his own Rolling Ball Records, and it's been getting noticed in Rolling Stone, The Huffington Post, American Songwriter, Elmore Magazine, All Music, Relix Magazine, Indie Shuffle, Paste and No Depression. His songs have been featured on ABC, CBS, NBC, CW and more, and his song "Find My Way" served as the song for the opening credits for the box office hit "The Proposal," starring Sandra Bullock.

Protest the Hero (often abbreviated as PTH or simply Protest) is a Canadian hardcore-influenced progressive metal band from Whitby, Ontario. The Protest line-up has stayed the same since the band formed in 1999, when they were just 12 years old.
performer.perf_keywords: Ontario; PTH; Protest; hardcore-influenced progressive metal band

performer.perf_description: This five-piece group is comprised of Albert Music Hall regulars.

Voted the #1 all-time female vocalist in Garageband's acoustic category in May of 2006, Liz Longley's textured voice evokes unconventional reactions from music lovers. The Philly native and Berklee School of Music grad is unquestionably a singer-songwriter of startling maturity.

Matt and Kim is an indie duo based out of Brooklyn, New York. Their keyboard-driven rock 'n' roll earned them a spot supporting Blink-182 and My Chemical Romance on select dates of the 2011 Honda Civic Tour and their songs are familiar from having been used in commercials (Bacardi and Mars Bar) and TV shows ('Chuck' and 'Entourage'). They are currently touring to support their latest work, 'Lightning,' which was released in October 2012.
Brooklyn's Elizabeth and The Catapult create jazzy, buoyant pop songs.
This three-piece Philadelphia band plays a mix of popular music, traditional Americana, and originals.

Like the sound in groups like Bloc Party and Interpol, Editors filter much of yesteryear's true post-punk (think Joy Division) through today's reality-TV prism. Editors are riding high on the singles 'Munich,' 'Bullets' and 'Blood.'

The Hooters first gained major commercial success in the United States in the mid 1980s due to heavy radio and MTV airplay of several songs including 'All You Zombies' and 'And We Danced.' Their unique blend of ska, reggae and rock 'n' roll was a fresh and powerful sound.
Armored Saint is a five-piece band based out of Los Angeles.

Aly & AJ Michalka have been performing together for almost a decade, not only as singers, but accomplished musicians. Both girls are quite proficient on keyboards and guitar. Citing musical influences such as Sting, Seal, Heart and John Mayer, to name but a few, Aly & A.J. have distilled the musical passion of those artists into their originals, songs that dwell on the life lessons and emotions they've already experienced.
performer.perf_keywords: Aly Michalka; AJ Michalka; sisters; family

performer.perf_description: Ricky Nelson Remembered is a unique multi-media entertainment event featuring the live music of Ricky Nelson's hit songs. The show is performed by Ricky's own twin sons Matthew and Gunnar and includes never before seen big screen video footage of the Nelson family with interviews from celebrities influenced by Ricky Nelson

Katie Herzig has been the lead singer of Newcomers Home, a Boulder, CO-based band, since she was a sophomore in college. Now based in Nashville, TN Katie is fully pursuing a solo career after the band played its last show and recently released her new solo cd, 'Weightless.'
Kentucky's own Black Stone Cherry cites influences from Led Zeppelin, Lynyrd Skynyrd, and Black Sabbath, but also a heavy side touching more in a Black Label Society vein.

Atkins is a blues-rock singer and songwriter based in Nashville. She co-wrote a song, "A Little Crazy," with Chris Isaak that was featured on the short-lived Cameron Crowe series, "Roadies" of 2016. She counts Roy Orbison as one of her chief influences.

Select Saturdays and Sundays, 1 pm to 5 pm. Stop by on weekends this spring and relax with a Crossing Cocktail, a frosty craft beer or wine by the glass. Enjoy live music (and dancing if you're in the mood!)A great way to "un-wined" after a busy work week. Check the website for details. No cover charge. Call for details: 215-493-6500, ext. 19 or email: info@crossingvineyards.com.

Lake Street Dive is a four-piece band from Boston that has made a mark in 2016. Rolling Stone describes them as "a young band steeped in Motown grooves, Muscle Shoals soul, Beatles melodies, Beach Boys harmonies, and pop divas from Dusty Springfield to Amy Winehouse to Adele." Of their first album, "Side Pony," RS wrote, " If it sometimes feels a bit calculated, it's still pretty irresistible."

Rebelution first united in Santa Barbara, California, built from musicians across a range of genres. With reggae as the focus, the group set out to create a fresh and vibrant sound which they dubbed "California Reggae."
performer.perf_keywords: Santa Barbara; California reggae; dub; Courage to Grow;

performer.perf_description: Dance Gavin Dance is a six-member post hardcore band from Sacramento, California.
performer.perf_keywords: fbseven Six-member post hardcore band; Sacramento

performer.perf_description: Craig Wedren is known as the former singer of Shudder to Think and now the singer for BABY.
Kyle is a hip-hop artist best known for his single, "iSpy."

Singer-multi-instrumentalist-composer Annie Clark performs as a solo (one-woman band) under the moniker "St. Vincent." Hailed by the Boston Globe as an "adorably spunky guitar prodigy," Annie has been seen opening for such acclaimed and diverse acts as Television and Jose Gonzalez. An inventive and versatile guitarist, Annie has played with avant-garde composer, Glenn Branca and is a member of symphonic pop spectacle The Polyphonic Spree.
performer.perf_keywords: Annie Clark; 2007 PLUG Awards Female Artist of the Year

performer.perf_description: Anthony Jeselnik is a stand-up comedian in high demand, most famous for "The Comedy Central Roast of Donald Trump" and "The Comedy Central Roast of Charlie Sheen," as well as "The Jeselnik Offensive," which he starred in and created. Jeselnik is known for his dark - verging on perverse - humor, which sometimes brings audiences face to face with raw truths not often mentioned in the stand-up world.

The Kooks (named for the song appearing on David Bowie's "Hunky Dory") met while attending Brighton Music College in the mid-2000s.
