Coffee & Jazz features over 20 jazz classics ranging across the past 100 years, including Duke Ellington's "it don't mean a thing if it ain't got that swing," to Irving Berlin's "Steppin' out with my Baby," to the biggest hit from the musical Chicago, "All that Jazz." Members of this 11-voice select ensemble will also perform a variety of solos and some duets, including the 1947 hit song, "What are you doing New Year's Eve?" Coffee & Jazz is presented in the City View Room on the 6th floor of MacAlister Hall (3250 Chestnut Street). There is an admission fee of $7 which can be paid at the door (cash and check only).

Join an animal habitat restoration project on Earth Day. Park rangers will lead an effort to remove invasive plants from a section of the park. Some native species will be planted. Individuals, families, and groups are welcome to attend. Bring work gloves. Loppers, pruning shears, and trowels are helpful if you have them. Learn to identify native vs. non-native plant species. Meet at the park office. Pre-registration is preferred.

performer.perf_name: Louis I. Kahn Memorial Award + Talk Featuring Sir David Adjaye
performer.perf_description: Join the Center for Architecture and Design for our 33rd Louis I. Kahn Memorial Award + Talk, honoring architect Sir David Adjaye OBE. Sir Adjaye is the principal and founder of Adjaye Associates. Born in Tanzania to Ghanaian parents, his broadly ranging influences, ingenious use of materials, and sculptural ability have established him as an architect with an artist's sensibility and vision. His largest project to date, the $540 million Smithsonian Institute National Museum of African American History and Culture, opened on the National Mall in Washington DC in fall of 2016 and was named Cultural Event of the Year by the New York Times. In 2017, he was knighted by Queen Elizabeth II and was recognized as one of the 100 most influential people of the year by TIME magazine.
performer.perf_keywords: Architecture;Architects;Kahn;AIA Philadelphia;Museum of African American History and Culture

performer.perf_description: This is the time of the year for Earth Day projects, and why should kids be left out? It is never too early to start learning about ways to help our earth. Wear clothes that you don't mind getting dirty. Join the park naturalist in an effort to make our park more beautiful. Make an Earth Day craft after we complete the project. Meet near the pavilions.

performer.perf_name: Redobles de Cultura: Afro-Puerto Rican Workshops & Jam
performer.perf_description: The powerhouse ensemble from NYC, Redobles de Cultura, heads out to Philly once more, this time in partnership with AfroTaino Productions and A Seed on Gallery, for an evening of learning, explorations and celebrating Afro-Puerto Rican music and dance. Regarded by many as young masters of the Bomba expressions, this team of masterful drummers, dancers and practitioners of the Puerto Rican expressions bring over 60 years' collective experience of teaching, performing and living these traditions. The evening will flow as follows: 5pm -6pm: Drum/percussion workshop, 6:30pm - 8pm: Dance workshop (open level, appropriate for men and women), 8:30pm - 11pm: Bombazo/Bomba party. $15 for each workshop (or $25 for both), $10 for Bombazo. For more information: rdcnyc8@gmail.com.

An estimated 1,800 people are expected to raise more than $200,000 at Walk MS: Philadelphia on May 5 at the Art Museum. Walk MS is an opportunity for people to come together with friends, loved ones and co-workers to fundraise, connect and advocate for people affected by MS. Each dollar raised is one step closer to the National Multiple Sclerosis Society's goal - a world free of MS. Since its inception in 1988, Walk MS has cumulatively raised more than $1 billion. "Walk MS is all about community - people coming together to raise money and show support for loved ones, colleagues and friends," said Cyndi Zagieboylo, President and CEO of the National MS Society. "Funds raised have a direct impact in this community, for example - our MS Navigator program. MS Navigators are highly-skilled, compassionate professionals available to connect each person affected by MS to the resources and information they need to live their best lives." When: Saturday, May 5 at 7:30 a.m., walk begins at 8:30 a.m. Where: Philadelphia Museum of Art, 2600 Benjamin Franklin Pkwy, Philadelphia 19130. Why Walk MS? Walk MS helps fuel groundbreaking MS research and provide life-changing services to those affected by MS through creating a supportive community of friends, families and loved ones who fundraise and connect. To find a walk near you, to participate or to volunteer, visit walkMS.org, call 855-372-1331 or email fundraisingsupport@nmss.org. Multiple sclerosis attacks the brain and spinal cord, and it is the most common neurological disease leading to disability in young adults. The National MS Society is a gathering place for people with MS, their family and loved ones, healthcare providers, volunteers, donors, fundraisers, advocates, community leaders and all those that seek a world free of MS. Sanofi Genzyme is the premier national sponsor of Walk MS. Biogen, Genentech and Novartis are national sponsors of Walk MS. About Multiple Sclerosis :Multiple sclerosis is an unpredictable, often disabling disease of the central nervous system that disrupts the flow of information within the brain, and between the brain and body. Symptoms range from numbness and tingling to blindness and paralysis. The progress, severity and specific symptoms of MS in any one person cannot yet be predicted, but advances in research and treatment are leading to better understanding and moving us closer to a world free of MS. Most people with MS are diagnosed between the ages of 20 and 50, with at least two to three times more women than men being diagnosed with the disease. MS affects more than 2.3 million worldwide. For more information about multiple sclerosis and the National MS Society go to nationalMSsociety.org or call 800-344-4867.

performer.perf_name: Big Oyster Brewery Concert Series - Volume One
performer.perf_description: Featuring Eleanor and the Roosevelts & Pet Cheetah.

performer.perf_name: Duel Of The Decades 90's Vs Y2K
performer.perf_description: 2 Decades. 1 Stage. YOU decide the winner! Two of the greatest cultural eras go head-to-head in the ultimate battle. A fun and unique evening of pop culture, Duel of the Decades is an interactive live music competition. Are you Team 90s or Team Y2K? Decades go back and forth competing in challenges with categories via the video gameboard. The audience determines the winner by voting LIVE from any mobile device. www.duelofthedecades.com

Find out why April's full moon is sometimes called the pink moon or the fish moon. The full moon name is applied to the entire month and is often tied in to what is happening in nature. This will be a meandering walk to enjoy the sounds and smells of spring. Meet in parking lot #2. Pre-registration is required.

performer.perf_name: Unleash Your Voice: Lessac Voice Workshop
performer.perf_description: In this one-day workshop, Lessac-certified teacher Roger Ainslie will help you unleash your voice's optimal, healthy, and true quality and maximum expressiveness. You were born with a great voice- it's true! But social conditioning, among other factors, has taken its toll on your voice over time. It's time to free that beautiful voice of yours to find its original, natural resonance and dynamics. Explore the methods developed by Arthur Lessac- a mix of mindfulness and playful discovery. Roger Ainslie is a professional actor, voice teacher, and dialect coach. Alongside a ton of regional theater, his television credits include House MD, iCarly, and House of Cards. He has also been teaching at various levels for over twenty years in Chicago, Los Angeles, and New York. Roger has an MFA from the University of Virginia, and is currently a professor of acting at Rowan University.

performer.perf_name: Undaunted by Dialects: Reliable, Repeatable Approach to Learning New Dialects
performer.perf_description: In this one-day workshop, dialect coach Roger Ainslie will help you build a solid, reliable, repeatable approach to learning new dialects. Having a good ear and/or being a good mimic can help you, but it won't take you as far as technique grounded in specifics! Most productions these days cannot or will not hire a dialect coach so it falls to the actors to coach themselves. Roger will teach you how! From basic vowel substitutions to melody and tempo to vocal posture and placement, Roger will take you through a step by step methodology. We will apply it to a specific accent over the course of the workshop, but by the end you will be able to use this technique for any dialect in any show you do. Roger Ainslie is a professional actor, voice teacher, and dialect coach. Alongside a ton of regional theater, his television credits include House MD, iCarly, and House of Cards. He has also been teaching at various levels for over twenty years in Chicago, Los Angeles, and New York. Roger has an MFA from the University of Virginia, and is currently a professor of acting at Rowan University.

Cinco de Mayo is coming and with it the kickoff of margarita season! Come celebrate at Howl at the Moon with our Blue Margarita Buckets* because there's no better way to enjoy a holiday than with a bucket of booze with your friends, singing along to a live band on stage and dancing the night away.
performer.perf_keywords: live music- drink specials- tequilla- party

performer.perf_description: Event run by Blackwell Library Teen Department. Please email Conita Pierson with any questions. Have you ever wanted to create your very own wearable, Smart Textile? Well now's your chance to sketch your idea and see what it's like to knit by code! Students will learn about the relationship between traditional knitting and modern­day digital fabrication of textiles. Notes: Workshop will be held in computer lab. Please ask front desk. Devices and snacks will be provided. Market Frankford El - 52nd & Market (going West or East). Bus Route 21 - 52nd & Chestnut (going West), 52nd & Walnut (going East). Bus Route 52 - 52nd & Chestnut (going South), 52nd & Walnut (going North).

Convened by the Atlantic County Workforce Development Board in collaboration with JEVS Human Services & Stockton University. The Youth Employment Symposium is an opportunity for local youth development providers, businesses, schools, and other stakeholders to share and learn about promising practices in youth employment, network with peer organizations and businesses, and brainstorm opportunities to build the region's network of stackable career development experiences for young adults. Featuring speakers: Simran Sidhu, The HIVE at Spring Point; Rhonda Lowery, Atlantic County Workforce Development Board; Michelle Carrera, Atlantic City Boys & Girls Club; Dr. Merydawilda Colon, Stockton University Center for Community Engagement; Chekemma Fulmore-Townsend, Philadelphia Youth Network; Dan Rhoton, Hopeworks N' Camden, Einstein Health Network; and John Colborn, JEVS Human Services.

Enjoy a magnificent display of spring ephemerals at our annual celebration of the season. Stroll through our native plant gardens at the peak of their glory; enjoy live music, gardening activities, family programming, and more. A variety of food selections are available for purchase and the first 1,000 families receive a free native plant. Free parking for this event is at 1003 Old Wilmington Road, just east of Brackenville Road. From the parking area, shuttle buses and a walking path provide access to the garden. Due to the rolling terrain and mulched paths at Mt. Cuba Center, the use of wheelchairs is limited. Pets are not permitted.

Commemorate America's public garden heritage with a visit to Mt. Cuba Center. Relax in our gardens, enjoy a picnic lunch, or take a leisurely stroll among spring wildflowers. Participate in family-friendly programs or guided walks from 10 am to 2 pm. Guests will take home a free native plant, while supplies last.

Celebrate the wonder of wildlife in our gardens. Get to know the insects, birds and animals that call our gardens and yards home and discover the joy of sharing your garden with your natural neighbors through family-friendly activities. A variety of food selections will be available for purchase. Each family receives a free native plant, while supplies last. For more information, visit our website: https://mtcubacenter.org

performer.perf_name: SALT Performing Arts: Titanic, The Musical
performer.perf_description: SALT Performing Arts presents the Tony Award winning drama, Titanic the Musical, April 13-29. The sinking of the Titanic in the early hours of April 15, 1912, remains the quintessential disaster of the twentieth century. The fact that the finest, largest, strongest ship in the world-called, in fact, the "unsinkable" ship-should have been lost during its maiden voyage is so incredible that, had it not actually happened, no author would have dared to contrive it. Maury Yeston and Peter Stone's musical examines the lives of the passengers aboard the doomed luxury liner Titanic - those in first class, middle class and steerage - in the nights leading up the ship's fatal encounter with an iceberg at sea. "When most people think of Titanic as a production, they think of the movie. Our show is actually more like a documentary-turned-musical," explains Lauren McComas, SALT President & Artistic Director. "Spanning all classes, Titanic captures the actual stories from the whole range of humanity aboard the ship: from boiler room workers to first-class attendants, from third-class ticketholders scraping together their lifesavings for the promise of the American dream, to some of the wealthiest men of the Victorian age, including John Jacob Astor and Benjamin Guggenheim. And yet the biggest character of the show is Titanic herself, and the actual events and timeline that led up to her sinking." Titanic will be the biggest and most spectacular production produced by SALT Performing Arts. The cast consists of 40 talented performers aging from 6 to 70 and a full live orchestra. Veterans and several talented SALT newbies make up this cast from Chester and the surrounding counties. Directed by Elizabeth Hennessey, Titanic runs approximately 2.5 hours with an intermission. Concessions are available for purchase in the lobby from Cookies by Design before the show and during intermission. Reserved seating is offered. Adults are $25 and Children ages 12 and under are $17. Handicap seating is also available. Tickets can be purchased at: https://www.saltpa.com/titanic-the-musical/ Please note: all ticket sales are final. Production Staff: , Elizabeth Hennessey, Director; David DiMarino, Music Director; Mike Toolan, Assistant Music Director; Lauren McComas, Producer & Assistant Director; Chelsea Barnett, Stage Manager; Kathy deVries, Costume Designer; Rob Merow, Set & Lighting Designer. The mission of SALT Performing Arts is to provide live community theatre productions, summer/year long theatre camps for kids, dinner theatre and more. With excellence as the standard, SALT, a non-profit organization, believes that the "community" is paramount in community theatre and strives to foster an all-inclusive atmosphere that promotes a positive, uplifting experience to each individual. SALT involves people of all ages from all walks of life. If you are interested in learning more about SALT Performing Arts, making a donation, or being a sponsor please email us at info@saltpa.com. SALT Performing Arts, Chester Springs, PA 19425 is organized and operated exclusively for charitable purposes with a non-profit 501(c)(3) status. For more information or to request interviews, contact Judy Elliott (jgelliott@saltpa.com) or visit our website (saltpa.com).
performer.perf_keywords: Chester County;Titanic The Musical;Chester Springs;Community Theatre;Local theater;Musical

performer.perf_description: Bring your lunch (beverages provided) and enjoy the second of two movies starring Judi Dench as Queen Victoria in unlikely friendships with servants. This 2017 historical flick won Dame Judi a Golden Globe nomination. The aging Queen Victoria becomes friends with Abdul Karim, a clerk come to the British court from India. The friendship scandalizes the royal family--given the superiority complext of white Anglo-Saxons towards other races of the British Empire, the court is outraged by the Queen's desire to elevate Abdul to knighthood. What effect will political intrigue have on Abdul, his family, and his friendship with Her Majesty? Rated PG-13 for occasional language. No signups required.

Join Maryville Addiction Treatment Center as we celebrate recovery and raise awareness for substance abuse treatment at the 11th annual Race for Recovery 5K and Fun Walk Sunday, June 24, 2018. The race will be held at Cooper River Park in Pennsauken, NJ with an 8 a.m. registration and 9 a.m. start with awards for 1st and 2nd place in several divisions. Just walking for the cause? You can walk as an individual or part of a team. The entry fee is $20 until June 1st, and $25 after. Children 10 and under are free. Proceeds from this event benefit the Peter P. Black IV Scholarship Fund at Maryville to assist individuals who are unable to pay for substance use disorder treatment. To register visit maryvillenj.org/upcoming-events.

performer.perf_name: First Ever Autism Day at Six Flags Great Adventure
performer.perf_description: Custom Ed Foundation and Gersh Academy are transforming Six Flags Great Adventure into a sensory-friendly environment for individuals on the autism spectrum. People with autism often struggle with sensory overload and have a hard time processing too much touch, taste, sight and sound--which makes visiting an amusement park next to impossible. The goal of this event is to remove those obstacles so families with children on the spectrum can not only attend the park but really enjoy it. This is the first time ever that an amusement park of the magnitude of Six Flags has been transformed into a sensory-friendly environment, and we are excited to make this event happen.

performer.perf_name: 6th Annual Ride for Recovery & Bike Show
performer.perf_description: Maryville Addiction Treatment Center will hold its 6th annual Ride for Recovery and Bike Show Sunday, May 6th, 2018. Registration starts at 9:30 a.m. with kickstands up at noon. The ride begins at Barb's Harley-Davidson, 926 Black Horse Pike in W. Collingswood Heights and ends at Maryville's Williamstown campus at 1903 Grant Avenue. A BBQ lunch will be held 1-4 p.m., along with the Battle of the Bikes contest. Show off your ride, with prizes for first, second and third place winners. Tickets for riders, passengers and BBQ-only are $20. Proceeds benefit the Peter P. Black IV Scholarship Fund at Maryville to assist individuals who are unable to pay for substance use disorder treatment. Sponsorships are available. Register online or become a sponsor at MaryvilleNJ.org.

Get all your questions answered at the 21st Annual Montgomery County Housing Fair on Saturday, April 28, 2018, from 10:00 AM to 2:00 PM at Plymouth Whitemarsh High School, 201 East Germantown Pike, Plymouth Meeting, PA. Over 30 exhibitors including government agencies, realtors, lenders, non-profit agencies and more will provide valuable information. Door-prize drawings will be held throughout the day including a $500 cash grand prize!

performer.perf_name: The School District of Philadelphia's Alll-City Jazz Festival
performer.perf_description: The Philly POPS and the Kimmel Center for the Performing Arts will present the School District of Philadelphia's All-City Jazz Festival. The day of free jazz performances by student and professional musicians will be held in the Kimmel Center's Perelman Theater and Commonwealth Plaza on Wednesday, April 18, 2018 from Noon - 9 p.m. This will be the POPS's fourth year presenting this event and the second year in partnership with the Kimmel Center. Throughout the day, a variety of student jazz programs, including from POPS in Schools, will take the stage. Professional POPS musicians will accompany students in the music-making and lead master classes in brass, percussion, rhythm, and winds. Students, parents, and the public will be invited to attend the day and evening performances. The 7 p.m. performance is a free, ticketed event with General Admission seating. Students and families should contact their school's music department to reserve tickets. Select tickets are available through registration. For all other ticket inquiries, please visit the Kimmel Center Box Office.

April's Third Thursday will be held on Thursday, April 19th from 6pm-9pm in Downtown Hammonton. Each month Downtown Hammonton businesses participate in an evening of extended hours, sales, specials and weather-permitted, outdoor entertainment. This month's theme is "A Garden Party," a celebration of all things spring. To add to the festivities, we invited several local artisans to set up along Bellevue Avenue to share their handmade products and provide an open air market experience.

performer.perf_name: Trace Water Contamination Sources Using ArcGIS Online
performer.perf_description: Have you ever wondered where your drinking water comes from? How about what might be in your water? Using a water quality dataset and an online map-making tool, ArcGIS, students will investigate where a fictitious source of groundwater pollution (based on real world data) may be originating. Students will learn about water quality issues, how to measure water quality, and how geospatial information can be used to solve problems involving water resources. Note: Please bring a laptop to this workshop.

performer.perf_name: Parenting From The Heart With Dr. Dan Gottlieb
performer.perf_description: About Dr. Gottlieb: Dr. Dan Gottlieb is a practicing psychologist but is best known as the host of ‘Voices in the Family', a weekly radio program heard for more than 30 years on NPR. "Voices in The Family" was an award winning mental health call in radio show. Currently, the show has moved from its weekly format to 6 times a year. About Dr. Gottlieb's Presentation: When we asked Dr Gottlieb about the essence of "Parenting From the Heart" he said; "Ever since Dr. Spock, we parents have been subjected to "guidance" from professionals. The dangers of too much discipline, and the dangers of not enough. Overindulging and neglected children are at risk. And now there is stranger danger! How did we survive without this advice ? We parented based on what was happening in our hearts rather than fearing what was in our heads". "Parenting From The Heart" will be about reclaiming the wisdom we were born with Dr. Gottlieb will present about Parenting from the Heart and How to change the difficult job of Parenting to one of JOY!
The Trevor Street Band is a Philadelphia-based cover band offering top-notch renditions of rock, blues and R&B classics.

Join us for Liguori Academy's Annual Boundless Celebration! The Boundless Celebration is an evening to revel in our accomplishments and honor those who support our mission. This fun event features a live concert performance by The Doo Wop Project, cocktails & light fare, and a live & silent auction. This year's recipient of the Boundless Award is Stan Woodland, CEO of CMI/Compas. Stan has been an integral supporter of Liguori since the school's inception, a true champion to our students representing the boundless motto. Sponsorship opportunities are available. Visit https://goo.gl/Bz5Kf5 for more information or please contact Shannon Donohoe: sdonohoe@liguoriacademy.org or 215- 571-1952: About The Doo Wop Project: The Doo Wop Project begins at the beginning, tracing the evolution of Doo Wop from the classic sound of five guys singing tight harmonies on a street corner to the biggest hits on the radio today. In their epic show, DWP takes audiences on a journey from foundational tunes of groups like the Crests, Belmonts, and Flamingos through their influences on the sounds of Smokey Robinson, The Temptations, and The Four Seasons all the way to DooWopified versions of modern musicians like Michael Jackson, Jason Mraz and Maroon 5. Featuring stars of Broadway's smash hits Jersey Boys and Motown: The Musical, the Doo Wop Project brings the unparalleled authenticity of sound and vocal excellence to recreate--and in some cases entirely reimagine--some of the greatest music in American pop and rock history! https://www.thedoowopproject.com. Liguori Academy is a 501(c)(3) organization. The Fair Market Value of this ticket is $100; only the portion of the contribution that exceeds this fair market value may be tax deductible.

performer.perf_name: Penn Wynne Library Annual Craft Fair & Book/Bake Sale
performer.perf_description: Join us for our annual Craft Fair fundraiser for the library! Browse and buy from local crafters, just in time to buy gifts for Mother's Day. There will also be a bake sale with treats made by Debbie Donnelly and Caked By Nanette. Weather permitting, the Library Board will hold a book sale on the library's front lawn.

Event run by TechGirlz. Please email Donna Cusimano with any questions. TechGirlz Summer Camp puts the tools and technology into the hands of 12-15 year old girls. The girls will learn programming, basic electronics, and engineering using the Arduino microcontroller. Using the Arduino IDE, campers will use the C and C++ programming languages, along with Arduino's supplied software library. They will write programs to perform multiple tasks that will allow their robots to navigate its surroundings. At the end of the week, campers will give a presentation and demonstration of their robots and take the Arduino robots home! More details can be found on our 2018 Summer Camp Web page. Please bring a laptop with a usb port to this event.

The Free Library of Philadelphia Is Celebrating the Benjamin Franklin Parkway Centennial ... Family Style! Experience the Library as never before as you enjoy art projects, games, storytelling, a scavenger hunt, a dinner buffet with kid-friendly food and adult-friendly beverages, and--of course--plenty of books! All proceeds benefit the critical programs offered in every community across the city by the Free Library of Philadelphia. By purchasing a ticket or becoming a Family Event sponsor today, you will help advance literacy, guide learning, and inspire curiosity for Philadelphians of all ages and backgrounds.

performer.perf_name: Alexander Hamilton -- The Man vs. The Musical
performer.perf_description: Recently, Alexander Hamilton has received increased attention and respect due to the blockbuster hit musical on Broadway - "Hamilton: An Americal Musical." There have been numerous people asking, "Is this show exaggerating Hamilton's importance during the founding era, or is it justifies?" Our speaker, Rand Scholet, compares and ranks Hamilton's contirbutions with seven other Founding Fathers. The speaker has a number of photos and personal anecdotes from his five-year relationship with the musical and its creative genius, Lin-Manuel Miranda, as well as Hamilton author Ron Chernow that inspired the musical." And Singing may be heard....

he Bucks-Mont Art League will hold their monthly meeting on Tuesday, May 15, 2018 at 6 pm in the Ben Wilson Senior Center, 580 Delmont Avenue, Warminster. Join like minded Artists and Art Lovers, Young & Old, and display your work at area locations. Come join in the fun.

performer.perf_name: Wyck Spring Lecture: The Rail Park with Aaron Goldblatt
performer.perf_description: Aaron will introduce the audience to the Rail Park, Phase 1 opening this spring, and the eventual 3-mile park running along the north edge of Center City. He will set the historical context for the site and give an overview of related projects in the US and internationally. He will also offer a brief history of the organization, Friends of the Rail Park, and the wide range of partnerships needed to create a beautiful celebration of our past and future. Aaron Goldblatt is a Partner with Metcalfe Architecture & Design, focusing on museum partnerships and services. Before joining Alan Metcalfe in 2002, Aaron served on the senior staff at Philadelphia's Please Touch Museum®, the Academy of Natural Sciences, and the Wagner Free Institute of Science. In each of those positions he was able to explore the tension and synergy between learning and play. He does both now at Metcalfe, in addition to mentoring, leading, and volunteering with community groups, including as a member of Friends of the Rail Park. Aaron holds a Master of Fine Arts from Rutgers University and a Bachelor of Fine Arts from the University of the Arts. This special evening will include a light supper and refreshments. Tickets are $35 for Friends of Wyck members and $45 for non-members. An additional discount will be available for those who join as members at the time of purchase.

Good music has a catchy rhythm, a hummable melody, and--if you're lucky--an unforgettable chorus. But great music has something else, something it's almost impossible to capture: soul. Enter Aloud. Henry Beguiristain and Jen de la Osa have been the core and soul of the band since their teens in Miami. A shared passion for rock classics like the Beatles, Oasis, Aretha Franklin, and Otis Redding led the pair to start writing and recording their own music. A relocation to Boston where deep ties were formed in the local rock scene, combined with connecting with Aloud's bassist, Charles Murphy pulled the band into focus. After one final relocation, this time to Los Angeles Aloud was brought into razor sharp focus. Dedicated musicianship pays dividends. First on local, then national tours, the band started honing a sound that has earned comparisons to the Alabama Shakes and the Black Keys. Their latest single, "Falling Out of Love", reveals an evolution of the band, showcasing their incredible harmonies in a soulful ballad reminiscent of the classic Muscle Shoals sound. The B-side gives listeners a glimpse into the band's formidable range; rock-edged with elements of psychedelia, "Empty House" is urgent, with a driving chorus you can't get out of your head. Together, the songs on the Falling Out of Lovesingle form a perfect bridge between the propulsive pop songs the band has been known for, and their upcoming full-length, a more heavily R&B-influenced effort featuring a full horn section. The upcoming album was produced by Grammy award winner Benny Grotto (Magnetic Fields, Ben Folds) and mixed by Guy Massey (Paul McCartney, Manic Street Preachers, The Libertines). For Aloud it's full steam ahead. According to de la Osa, this is just the beginning.

The Notre Dames Ladies Gaelic Football Club are hosting their annual scavenger hunt / pub crawl in Philadelphia this spring called the Dames Dash (www.DamesDash.com). They've been holding this event since 2014, and people really enjoy it. It entails participants doing silly activities along a pub crawl to gather points, and eventually win a prize at the end of the event. It starts at Fox & Hound in Center City, followed by an after party at Slainte near 30th Street Station.

ExL's 9th Aggregate Spend and Open Payments Conference has been the industry's premier event for strategies to optimize transparency reporting for compliance programs for almost a decade. This year, we will explore compliance theories about how to match transparency-reporting processes with continually evolving business systems and promotional activities.

Admission is free! Doors are at 6 and show is at 8:30. Don't be late.

The idealistic son of a wealthy businessman seeks to destroy his philandering father's reputation by exposing an ancient extramarital affair, which will also free his childhood friend from the delusions and lies on which his happy marriage is based. Meanwhile, an ambitious young inventor spends so much of his time and energy trying to devise an invention which will make him rich that he is unaware of the true richness of his daily life. Does the truth or money set us free, and should it be pursued whatever the cost? Or is it better to enjoy life's simple joys and to allow the past and its buried secrets to remain so?

Varla Jean Merman's new show pays tribute to the inspiring women who have inspired her to think about becoming inspirational. Don't miss this special one night only opportunity to see Varla in Philly this year! Jeffery Roberson aka Varla Jean Merman starred in the new musical Lucky Guy opposite Leslie Jordan in NY at the Little Schubert in 2011 prompting The New York Times to rave, "If Carol Burnett and Harvey Korman had stood in front of the right pair of funhouse mirrors, they might have resembled Ms. Merman and Mr. Jordan in stature as well as comedic talent"! You've also seen Varla Jean on Project Runway, on stage in the super-gay seaside village of Provincetown, and on the Big Screen in "Girls Will Be Girls".

performer.perf_description: Two solo exhibitions featuring the work of Anthony Campuzano and Jenny Cox, who both use text, mark-making, and color as the foundation for drawing.

The stand that started it all - carrying on Alex Scott's lemonade stand tradition and her dream of curing childhood cancer! Come to one of ALSF's most important stands of the year and help the fight against childhood cancer. Join Alex's family, friends and community as they honor the tradition of her annual lemonade stand. This family-friendly event is free and features food, games, crafts, face-painting, music, raffle items and - of course - plenty of lemonade! Since 2005, this event has brought in over $1 million to support Alex's vision of better treatments and cures for kids with cancer. Alex's All Access Passes are available for $25 each, which includes a t-shirt and all donations for activities and food. Sponsorship and Family Packages are also available.
performer.perf_keywords: family;kids;lemonade stand;charity;fundraiser;Alex's Lemonade Stand Foundation;Penn Wynne

performer.perf_name: Ladies for Lemons: Networking for a Cause & Vendor Fair
performer.perf_description: Ladies for Lemons (L4L) will host a networking for a cause and vendor fair to benefit the Gavin Strong Fund for Neuroblastoma Research through Alex's Lemonade Stand Foundation (ALSF). This event is made possible by sponsors MaGerks Pub and Planning & Publicity by Tracy T. Nyszczot (PPbyTT), volunteers, the Morris Family and their dear Gavin whose inspiring memory the event will celebrate. Ladies for Lemons is a circle of women coming together to empower each other for a cause and includes event sponsors, vendors, supporters and partners. Professional men and women are invited to network, while mingling and enjoying cocktails and the vendor fair upstairs. Tickets are a Choose-Your-Own donation with all money going toward the Gavin Strong Fund through ALSF. Or eat at MaGerks all day on Thursday, May 3 and they will donate 15% of your bill to the cause. Visit Ladies for Lemons fundraising page for updates on the event details, new vendors and supporters. The upstairs at MaGerks does not have an elevator; please contact MaGerks for accommodations.
performer.perf_keywords: Vendor Fair;Networking;Childhood cancer;charity;fundraiser;Alex's Lemonade Stand Foundation

Disney's hit musical, all about the young news boys who go on strike in NYC in 1899, filled with exciting choreography and a great score.

Chef Marc Vetri hosts The Great Chefs Event Philadelphia on Saturday, June 9. This exclusive culinary event, presented by Northwestern Mutual and Volvo, brings together over 40 superstar chefs from across the country to serve signature tasting dishes at Urban Outfitters HQ in the Philadelphia Navy Yard. Newly revamped as a daytime, family-friendly experience, guests will dine from 12:30 to 4 pm to benefit Alex's Lemonade Stand Foundation (ALSF). As in years' past, Marc Vetri has hand-selected the list of participating chefs, inviting friends and respected colleagues from LA, NYC, Chicago, Italy and more to share their signature dishes. The chefs will donate their time, talent and food, creating delicious samplings indicative of their own personal styles. Participating chefs include recently announced 2018 James Beard Award Finalists Michael Cimarusti (L.A.), Evan Funke (L.A.), Michael Solomonov (Philadelphia), Andy Ticer and Michael Hudman (both from Memphis) and many more renowned chefs. For complete chefs list, visit GreatChefsEvent.org.

Retreat from 5/18-5/20! A three day, two night ocean front beachhouse in the heart of Ventnor City, New Jersey. Steps away from the ocean, a picturesque boardwalk. Professionally prepared fresh, healthy meals (breakfasts, dinners and snacks included). We will accomadate food allergies and vegan, vegitarian + GF choices. There are 10 sleeping spaces in the house and 11 commuter spots available for an intimate, yet profound experience as well as amazing networking. Powerful group intention setting. Private yoga instructor for the ultimate soul workout experience held at the house or on the beach (weather permitting). Daily transformational workshops that will be broken up into small groups for a personalized experience. Daily meditations & group healing to clear, release and rejuvinate your body, mind, soul. Time for relaxation and self reflection to enjoy the house and beautiful surroundings. Powerful manifesting rituals to raise your vibration like never before. Workshops led by spiritual leaders to guide you through clearing limitations, opening your intuition, building confidence in your personal power and developing manifestation tools to create an even more amazing life of self mastery.

performer.perf_name: Paul Barrere & Fred Tackett: Little Feat's Guitarists
performer.perf_description: Paul Barrere & Fred Tackett, the two guitarists from the legendary Little Feat, can't seem to get enough of each other. They first played together on the album "Dixie Chicken" some forty-five years ago and since then have played together or individually on numerous recording sessions for Little Feat and countless others including Bonnie Raitt, Taj Mahal, Bob Dylan, Tom Waits and the Wallflowers to name a few. Paul Barrere penned or cowrote "Feats Don't Fail Me Now," "All That You Dream," "Let It Roll" and "Hate To Loose Your Lovin.'" These days, when not touring with Feat, they like to unplug and share a laid back evening of Little Feat hits and more.

performer.perf_name: Jamie McLean Band & Greg Sover Band
performer.perf_description: Jamie McLean is a triple threat familiar to ST94 fans. His southern soul vocals ooze raw emotion and his top line songwriting chops tie everything together. With hundreds of original compositions to his name McLean creates a musical gumbo that incorporates New Orleans soul, Delta blues, middle America roots and New York City swagger. Greg Sover Band is off to a great start this year! Greg released a new EP 'Jubilee' in January and it's getting great reviews and airplay nationally and internationally. The band made it to the semifinals at The International Blues Challenge in Memphis. They're excited to return to Sellersville twice this year so far!

performer.perf_name: Heart By Heart with Original Heart Members Steve Fossen & Michael Derosier
performer.perf_description: In 2013 bassist Steve Fossen and drummer Michael Derosier were inducted into the Rock & Roll Hall Of Fame as original members of Heart. That 1970s lineup brought to the world the massive radio hits "Magic Man," "Crazy On You," "Dreamboat Annie," "Barracuda," "Kick It Out," "Heartless," "Straight On," "Dog & Butterfly," "Even It Up" and much more. Now Fossen and Derosier are back together with Heart By Heart, a new band featuring powerhouse vocalist Somar Macek, multi-talented guitarist/keyboardist/vocalist Lizzy Daymont, and legendary Seattle guitarist Randy Hansen. Honoring the magic and power of the music of Heart, this incredible lineup considers it their responsibility to bring the songs to the stage in their original form.

performer.perf_name: German Men's Chorus Annual Spring Concert
performer.perf_description: We are delighted to invite you to our annual Spring Concert. The Franklinville Schwarzwald Männerchor (The Philadelphia German Men's Chorus) will be joined by the Damenchor Wald-Echo (German Ladies Chorus) and guest instrumentalists, in a program that includes classical pieces by Mozart, Beethoven and Handel; German folk songs and drinking songs; songs celebrating the arrival of Spring; and also songs in English including the famous Drinking Song from the "Student Prince"; "I'll See You Again" by Noel Coward, and a charming arrangement of an old railroad Work Song, "Drill Ye Tarriers, Drill!". All of the pieces are sung in four-part harmony. The Männerchor and Damenchor will each sing several songs separately, and then join together for a grand finale of the two choruses. Jacqueline Smith leads this concert of folk, popular, and classical music. The concert takes place in the beautiful VE Club, nestled in over 60 acres of wooded Warminster. After the concert, there will be music for social dancing. Food and drink are available for purchase, including a full bar.

performer.perf_name: Jenkintown Music Theatre: Chicago the Musical
performer.perf_description: Jenkintown Music Theatre is proud to present its 2018 Production, "Chicago the Musical." Set in the roaring, jazz-hot 20s, Chicago explores themes of celebrity, corruption and scandal as it tells the story of rival murderesses and Cook County Jail inmates Velma Kelly and Roxie Hart. A media "circus" ensues when Velma and Roxie enlist slickster lawyer Bill Flynn. Winner of the 1975 Tony for Best Musical and 2002 Oscar for Best Picture, JMT's Chicago is sure to razzle dazzle you from start to finish.

performer.perf_name: Merion Concert Band: Women of Note
performer.perf_description: Women represent more than half of the world's population. They make up around 40 percent of American employees classified as working musicians, singers, or those in related professions. Yet, women composers often represent less than 2 percent of programming scheduled by America's largest orchestras. It's time for that to change. Join the Merion Concert Band as we celebrate female composers and their contributions to the concert band repertoire. In a performance jointly directed by Conductor Nathan Snyder and Assistant Conductor Ashley Smith, we pay long-neglected and well-deserved homage to women in music. The band will be joined by vocal soloist Julie Bishop for the four movement work, Image in Stone. From opera and marches to modern fanfares and beautiful ballads, come enjoy an afternoon of music featuring works by living female composers. Program: Early Light - Carolyn Bremer Celebration Fanfare - Joan Tower (arr. Jack Stamp) Women of the Podium - Virginia A. Allen Image in Stone - Stephen McNeff (Julie Bishop, vocal soloist) One Life Beautiful - Julie Giroux Maiden Voyage - Shirley Mier Kokopelli - Anne McGinty Journey Through Orion - Julie Giroux

performer.perf_name: Book Signing with Warminster Author Steven Donahue
performer.perf_description: Join us at the Warminster Township Free Library on May 5 at 2 pm for a book talk with local author Steven Donahue. Donahue is the author of Where Freedom Rings: A Tale of the Underground Railroad, the thrilling story of four slaves who try to escape the northern area of the United States along the Underground Railroad in 1853. A Q&A session and book signing will follow. No registration required.

A variety of food trucks and vendors will be on hand for patrons to enjoy amazing food and drinks. Some of the most popular trucks in the region will be participating, including: Poi Dog Philly, Chewy's, Pizza Wagon, Zsa's, Spurrito, Taco Mondo and more.

The Practitioners of Musick will return to Washington Crossing Historic Park (PA) on Saturday, April 28 at 7 p.m. in the park's Visitor Center auditorium. Founded in 1999, the Practitioners of Musick survey the music of 17th- and 18th-century Great Britain, Ireland and America. Their performance will feature music based upon the surviving inventory of printed music owned by various members of the Washington/Custis family and music that was popular among 18th-century Virginia playhouses and concert rooms. Also performing that night will be the Germantown Country Dancers. The Practitioners of Musick features John Burkhalter on recorder and Donovan Klotzbeacher on harpsichord. The duo has performed at numerous historic sites as well as libraries, museums and universities throughout the East Coast.

Join us at the American Swedish Historical Museum on April 17th as we explore some of Sweden's favorite dairy treats. This event is a wonderful opportunity for our youngest audience to learn where dairy products like milk and cheese come from and experience some special Swedish dairy farm traditions. Farmers from What-Knott Farm will join us and bring the guest of honor, a calf! In addition to the live animal presentation, toddlers will enjoy a themed story, get a chance to "milk" their own cow, and enjoy a Swedish dairy inspired snack. The cost is $5 per session (free for museum Household members'children/accompanying caregivers). Register online or pay at the door. Toddler Time is our specially designed program for children ages 18 months to 4 years old, where each session helps young minds grow through interactive stories, engaging hands-on activities and social interaction. Toddler Time is a monthly program, every third Tuesday of the Month.

Explore the colorful history of racing in Bucks County, PA and the nearby Delaware Valley, from the footraces of early Native Americans and colonists, to the horse tracks and fairgrounds of the 1800s, to the auto speedways and bicycle velodromes of the 20th century. Objects on view include original cars that once raced on local tracks, vintage cycling gear, harness racing sulkies and more. Test out your skill and speed with some racing "try-its."

Meet ground-breaking African-American motor racers in this panel and discussion program, led by driver, owner and entrepreneur Leonard Miller. Program includes a preview of a soon-to-be released documentary about Miller, the Black American Racers Association, and his efforts to break the color barrier in motor sports. A restored Formula "Super Vee" raced by Miller's team is also on view, courtesy of the Volkswagen Group of America.

Join several drag racers, mechanics and engine builders as they remember the action and atmosphere of local drag strips in the 1950s and 1960s. Guests are encouraged to bring their own memorabilia and stories to share.

Medford Township and the Woman's Club of Medford invite all local residents and community groups to participate in its Sixth Annual Town Wide Yard Sale to be held Saturday, April 28, 2018 from 7:30 a.m. to 2:00 p.m. at Freedom Park, located at 86 Union Street. There is no cost to participate in the Yard Sale, but items offered for sale should be "pre-loved", created from repurposed materials, or be plants. All sales and proceeds go to the participating individual or community group. Participants must provide their own table(s) and chairs for an approximate 10' x 10' location. Pre-registration is requested by April 21, 2018 to medfordwomansclub@gmail.com.
Help make delicious kamishbroit filled with jams and chocolate chips. Sale at 3:30 p.m.

Want to know what L.A.'s punk rock scene was like in the late `70s/early `80s? This legendary doc puts you in the middle of the mosh pit! Includes performances and interviews with X, Fear, Black Flag, Circle Jerks, Germs and more.

performer.perf_name: "My Israel 70 Story" with Bat El Trabelsi, Jewish Federation's Shaliach (Emissary) from Israel
performer.perf_description: In celebration of Israel's 70th birthday as an independent state, Bat El will share her family's personal story which includes Aliyah, Sephardi and Mizrahi Jews and the connection of all the Jews around the world.

Go behind the scenes of our historic ships like never before. Experience the engine room and brig on Cruiser Olympia and scope out the conning tower on Submarine Becuna. Tour areas that are usually closed off to the public on these National Landmark ships. Behind the scenes tours take place the first Saturday of each month. Tours last for approximately one hour and are for visitors 13 years and older. Regular Museum admission is included in the cost of the tour. For additional information, please contact Greg Williams, Shipboard Educator at 215-413-8679 or gwilliams@phillyseaport.org.

performer.perf_name: "Jerusalem: To Whom it Belongs... Why & When?" with Dr. David Rabeeya
performer.perf_description: Dr. David Rabeeya, WEL Main Line Resident and Professor, will present in recognition of Yom Yerushalayim, Jerusalem Reunification Day.

performer.perf_name: "Chekhov & His Friends: Art & Architecture in Turn of the Century Moscow" with Dr. Jim Curtis
performer.perf_description: Dr. Curtis' presentation will feature Jewish artist, Isaac Levitan and will have a broad appeal because of Chekhov's popularity and influence.
Summerside on the Hill offers a variety of camps for all ages and interests throughout the summer. Come for one week or stay for all 10 weeks.

performer.perf_description: Join us for a fun-filled day of golf, food, raffles and prizes. With the fire in November 2017, all proceeds raised this year will support our renewal efforts moving forward. 11:00 A.M. Registration and Lunch, 12:30 P.M. Tee Off Scramble. Golfer and sponsorship registration deadline: May 21st. Dinner Only registration deadline: May 28th. Can you love someone back to life? Romeo and Juliet have been dead a year. The feuding households of Montague and Capulet must reckon with their shared blame and relive the star-crossed lovers' final days. In our intimate, six-actor version of Shakespeare's play, the original text is inventively reconstructed to become a vibrant act of redemption and reconciliation. Approximately 90 minutes. -- Written by William Shakespeare -- Conceived for six actors by Zak Berkman & Samantha Reading -- Adapted and Directed by Samantha Reading --- ACCESSIBILITY: There will be a Relaxed Performance of Romeo & Juliet on May 27th at 2pm. For information about engagement and accessibility for this production, visit the production page on our website (peopleslight.org) or call the box office at 610.644.3500.

A powerful photography exhibition empowering women with varying disabilities. The project seeks to raise awareness of the women's strength, sensuality and spirit, and in the process, change perceptions of beauty.

performer.perf_name: Bottles & Brushes: A Sommelier Paint Night
performer.perf_description: Join us as we celebrate the arrival of spring, with an exploration and complimentary tasting of wines that perfectly pair with sunshine and spring flowers. Ava, your art entertainer, will guide you towards "uncorking your creative art side" and instruct a beautiful cherry blossom tree design on a wine glass based on our lovely blossoms at West Laurel Hill's Arboretum. What makes this wine and paint night unique is that Serena will be your sommelier for the evening to teach you tips and tricks to sip wine like a pro! Sip and Paint as you relax the evening away at West Laurel Hill. Tickets are $50 and includes 3 hours of wine tasting, glass painting and lite bites. All materials will be provided so you can paint, while you sip and enjoy! Details of wine selection tbd. For more information, email events@westlaurelhill.com or (610) 668-9900.
Join us for Dr. David Rabeeya's lecture. For more information about the lecture, contact Dr. Rabeeya via email at Sephardici@aol.com.

The Penn State Extension Master Gardeners offer all day garden workshops, tours, talks and special science in the garden activities for youth as part of the Philadelphia Science Festival. Free soil lead testing, and a huge range of affordable seedlings and plants to grow in your garden. Learn about growing vegetables, cooking with herbs, planting for pollinators, container gardening, composting and more.

performer.perf_description: The growing biotech industry has led to an increasingly competitive and saturated marketplace, and with it, greater competition for face time with premier thought leaders. Coupled with the scrutiny associated with industry partnerships and the challenges of managing KOL relationships in a post-Sunshine Act world, it is imperative for life science organizations to differentiate themselves from their competitors in the marketplace while aligning company objectives across their internal organization. The 9th KOL/Thought Leader Engagement and Advisory Boards Summit will provide attendees with valuable insights into engaging traditional and non-traditional KOLs and discuss the priorities and motivating factors for patient groups, payers and managed care organizations. Join our esteemed faculty as they share disruptive techniques for attracting external stakeholders in meaningful ways and discuss strategies for commercial and medical groups to work together while maintaining compliance. URLs:Tickets: https://go.evvnt.com/216211-1?pid=3075. Brochure: https://go.evvnt.com/216211-3?pid=3075. Speakers: Kevin Appareti, Senior Director, Global MSL, PHILIPS, William Soliman, Executive Chair, ACMA, Usman Iqbal, Senior Director, Medical Affairs and HEOR, Trevena, Gail Rosen Spahn, Senior Director, Medical Sciences, Xenosport, INC, Chijioke O. Madugwulike, Senior Manager, Clinical and Health Economics Outcomes Research, Osiris Therapeutics, INC, Pamela Appel, Director, Strategic Support and External Engagement, Global Clinical Development and Medical Affairs, Pfizer, Joshua Corriveau, Medical Science Liaison, Dermatology/ Rheumatology, Novartis, Peter Kowey, M.D., FACC, FHRS, FAHA, Professor of Medicine and Clinical Pharmacology, Jefferson Medical College, The William Wikoff Smith Chair in Cardiovascular Research, Lenkenau Hospital and Medical Research Center, Gail Spahn, Executive Director, Scientific Affairs, AcelRX, Milijana Drobnjak, Regional Director of Sales, Gilead Sciences, Natalia Borinshteyn, President, LIFE Science Excellence Inc., Leslie Bloom, Director, Scientific Education and Patient Advocacy, Johnson and Johnson, Yurek Paprocki, Medical Lead Director, Novo Nordisk, Brandi Howard, VP, Global Clinical Development and Medical Affairs, Innovative Women's Healthcare Solutions, Amphora, Evofem Biosciences, Welton O'Neal, Head of Medical Affairs, Supernus Pharmaceuticals, Vicki L. Fisher, Director, Operations and Training, Medical Affairs, Jazz Pharmaceuticals.

Phoenixville Public Library will host a free talk, "Clear Your Clutter", on Thursday, April 26 at 7:00 PM. Clutter clearing practitioner Katya Wieber will be the speaker. Have you ever noticed how tired or overwhelmed you feel when your house is cluttered? Energy starts stagnating and your home feels dull. When your home is clutter free, energy flows and the space feels vibrant! Katya will talk about what clutter clearing is and how clutter affects you, and will offer tips on how to get started to lead a clutter free life. She will share stories on how releasing clutter has transformed her clients' lives. Come hear how clutter clearing can transform your life and move you from chaos to clarity. There will be a question and answer period after the talk. Katya Wieber is a clutter clearing practitioner trained by the leading expert in the field, Karen Kingston, author of Clear Your Clutter with Feng Shui. This event is free and open to the public. Reservations are required on the Adult Events Calendar at www.phoenixvillelibrary.org or by calling 610-933-3013 x132.

performer.perf_name: ‘The Greatest Show on Dirt:' Automobile Racing at Langhorne Speedway
performer.perf_description: Dr. Alison Kreitzer, adjunct faculty member at the University of Delaware, discusses the expansion of automobile racing in Pennsylvania during the first half of the twentieth century, including the local fair circuit and Langhorne Speedway, one of the nation's first tracks built purposely for motor racing.

Experience some of the ways kids in our area race and compete. Participants include Pinewood Derby racers from the Washington Crossing Council, Boy Scouts of America; the Oaklane Quarter Midget Club, Trumbauersville; and the Bucks County Soapbox Derby. Visit with the racers, and join in activities scheduled throughout the day.

performer.perf_name: Once Upon a Time... Exploring the World of Fairy Tales
performer.perf_description: Step inside the larger-than life pages of beloved fairy tales from around the globe including Cinderella, Beauty and the Beast, and Jack and the Beanstalk in this hands-on exhibition. Once Upon A Time... Exploring the World of Fairy Tales is a collaborative effort of the St. Louis Public Library and The Magic House, St. Louis Children's Museum and is made possible by a grant from the Institute of Museum and Library Services.

By the end of the hour, you'll have an arsenal of moves that you can use with or without a lap to dance on. So whether you're looking to bring home a sexy routine or you just want to have fun and sweat away some calories, this dance party will leave you feeling strong and empowered. Ages 21 and up, no dance experience required. Wind, twirl and dip around a chair to create a simple routine that you can easily replicate at home. If time permits, we'll even teach a couple of more advanced moves involving rolls or balances.

Glow, get low and ignite some serious fire in your muscles at our black light fitness party! Join us for an exhilarating glow-light rock concert where everyone gets to be the star drummer! The Ripstix used for POUND Fitness classes just so happen to light up under black lights, so we're amping it up at our Midtown studio with this extended workshop featuring 90 minutes of energizing drum fitness routines. POUND pro duo, Lehla and Maureen, will take turns leading this full-body jam session, which uses simulated drumming with lightly weighted sticks to burn calories and tone muscle. Relieve stress and get a killer workout at the same time as you "pound" along to great music. Expect a mix of cardio, Pilates, isometric poses, plyometrics and plenty of strength conditioning: squats, lunges, hip-raises, arm swings, squats and lunges. We guarantee you'll feel the impact of this party in all the best ways. No prior drumming or POUND experience required. Maureen and Lehla will break down the form and any tricky combinations so that everyone can unleash their inner rock stars. We'll bring the sticks, mats, light refreshments (with neon plastic cups of course!) and maybe even some glow-in-the-dark accessories. All you need to do is show up ready to sweat. If you can, wear white or neon to add to the color fun! Space is limited by the number of Ripstix, so please pre-register to reserve your spot.

Three hundred students are set to go head to head in this underwater competition. Teams designed remotely operated vehicles (ROVs) to complete mission tasks underwater, technical documents, marketing displays and presentations for university and industry judges. The top three Ranger overall winners will move onto MATE International, Seattle, WA, June 21-23, 2018. Contact: Velda Vanessa Morris, Regional Coordinator.

performer.perf_name: Beacon Theatre Productions: Freud's Last Session by Mark St. Germain
performer.perf_description: "Freud's Last Session," directed by Beacon Theatre Productions's Artistic Director Georgina Bard and featuring actors Sam Gugino as Sigmund Freud and David Burgess as C.S. Lewis, centers on legendary psychoanalyst, Dr. Sigmund Freud who invites the young, rising Oxford Don, C.S. Lewis, to his home in London. On the day England enters World War Two, Freud and Lewis clash about love, sex, the existence of God, and the meaning of life. A deeply touching play filled with humor and exploring the minds, hearts, and souls of two brilliant men as they address the greatest questions of all time. Show dates: April 13 at 8pm, April 14 at 8pm, April 15 at 2pm April 20 at 8pm, April 21 at 8pm, April 22 at 3pm. Special post-show events: April 14 - Guest Speaker Tony Lawton - April 15 - Talkback with the actors and director.

performer.perf_name: Rainbow Children, Angel Babies & Fruitless Fig Trees
performer.perf_description: Written & performed by Veronique LaShell MacRae- and directed by Cynthia L. Dorsey. Inspired by the structural format of "For Colored Girls..." and "Women on Fire" this piece is an exploration of infertility, loss and barrenness in support of pregnancy and infant loss awareness. Through a series of monologues, song and dance, "Rainbow Children, Angel Babies and Fruitless Fig Tress" expresses the stages of grief (denial, anger, bargaining, depression and acceptance) for those who have experienced loss or inability to have children. World Premiere.at The 2nd Annual Shoe Box Short Theatre Festival. More information available at www.vlashproductions.com.
performer.perf_keywords: theatre;one woman show;infertility awareness;rainbow children;drama;world premiere

Legacy Treatment Services, a nonprofit human service agency, invites competitors to show off their trivia skills and sign up for the benefit "Night of Trivia" at Ramblewood Country Club & Seven Tap Tavern in Mount Laurel. Legacy's third annual trivia event features seven rounds of trivia hosted by South Jersey's The Quiz Kids. Participants can enjoy food and drinks while competing to win prizes. Individuals can purchase tickets for $50, which includes food stations and soft drinks, or teams of eight players can register for $350. Participants who do not have a full team will be placed with additional players to make up a team of eight. There will also be basket and silent auctions and a 50/50 raffle. Proceeds from the event support Legacy Treatment Services and its behavioral health and addictions services for children, adults and families. For more information, or to sign up a team, call 609-288-3127 or visit www.legacynightoftrivia.com.
Full day conference for pre- and post-foster and adoptive parents, social workers and adoptees.

performer.perf_description: Would you like to take a private flight over Bucks County, spend the night in New Hope, or vacation in VT? The Annual Auction for Wrightstown Friends Nursery School is just around the corner. All are welcome to come and bid on fabulous silent and live auction items like these and more. From dinner and a movie to beautiful hand made items such as garden planters to spa packages...big and small there is something for one and all! Come enjoy the fun, food and unique items to be won! donations@wrightstownfriends.org

Parenthood isn't often glamorous. It's hard to make time for a special night out - and daunting to juggle the logistics of picking the place, feeding the kids and getting the sitter. PlayArts Parent Cocktail Hour is the perfect solution for an effortless sophisticated night out. You've never seen PlayArts like this. We're transforming our event space into your date night dream. We've partnered with Blue Coat Gin and Root Restaurant to offer three curated cocktails, spectacular hors d'oeuvres and childcare. We've even got your ride home covered with an exclusive event discount from Lyft! Make it a date! $75/adult, all-inclusive ticket includes adult food and beverage, on-site childcare, pizza and movie for 1 child. Add children for $15/child. Invite friends: $250/four adult all-inclusive tickets including food and beverage, on-site childcare, pizza and movie for up to 3 children. Add children for $15/child. Space is limited. Tickets must be purchased in advance by Friday, April 13 at 5 p.m. Future Cocktail Hours Friday, May 18 Stateside & Good Spoon Soupery Friday, June 22 New Liberty & 13th Street Kitchens PlayArts is a bright, engaging playspace in Fishtown, custom built and designed for your child's imagination. We offer event rentals, afterschool, camp, art classes, music lessons and co-working with childcare.

performer.perf_name: DanceVisions Presents: HUMAN by Nora Gibson Contemporary Ballet
performer.perf_description: "Human" is a post-human ballet that uses form and context to consider otherness and objectivity. This anti-story imagines an AI being who moves in and outside of human patterned constructs, forests, and time. "Human" is a ballet that uses a traditional idiom to consider future sensibility. The work is choreographed by Nora Gibson, with an original music score by noted ambient electronic composer Michael McDermott (AKA Mikronesia). This evening-length ballet features a cast of five outstanding dancers, Marria Cosentino-Chapin, Brian Cordova, Sean Thomas Boyt, Katharine Nace, and Hallie Lahm. Nora Gibson premieres her new work, "Human," as the inaugural recipient of the Performance Garage's Dr. RJ Wallner DanceVisions Residency. The Residency was designed by Executive Director Jeanne Ruddy in order to support a Philadelphia dance artist who exhibits exceptional talent. The inaugural year is supported by a generous gift from Dr. RJ Wallner. Ms. Gibson was selected for her ability to thoroughly immerse her audiences in her work through her meticulous choreography, careful lighting design, and use of original music scores. The Performance Garage is proud to support her innovative work. Run time is approximately 40 minutes. An artist Q&A will follow the Sunday, April 22 performance. Please note that haze will be used during the performance
performer.perf_keywords: ballet;dance performance;dance residency;resident artist;Performance Garage;Philadelphia arts

performer.perf_name: Burlington County Gardeners Association: "For the Love of Tomatoes"
performer.perf_description: The wonderfully delicious Jersey Tomato! Learn how to grow the many different sizes, shapes and colors of this favorite Garden State crop. Open to the public, no pre-registration required.

Shipwrecked, stranded, and separated, twins Viola and Sebastian each fears the other lost. Using her wits, Viola disguises herself as a page boy and stumbles into a love triangle that upends the island of Illyria. Join Shakespeare in Clark Park for a glam rock exploration of the Bard's classic romance featuring some of Philadelphia's finest student musicians alongside professional actors in a land where music is the food of love. In this "Twelfth Night," anything can happen.

Cuban and American history converge in this original play exploring cultural exploitation, race, embargoes, conquistadores, and the relationship between two countries that are really, really close together. ¡Bienvenidos! Welcome! What a pleasure! Please come in. Slap some suntan lotion onto that pale white skin and press those little piggies into the soft white sand. Take in the Tropicana ladies with their sultry caderas (translation: "hips!") and feel the exotic lure of that Afro-drumbeat bouncing off the tops of swaying palm trees. Our translators are ready, and the soldiers have been paid off. Don't look over there, that's just a long history of exploitation. Can we offer you a top-up on that mojito?

"What does it mean to defend the dead? To tend to the Black dead and dying: to tend to the Black person, to Black people, always living in the push toward our death?" Christina Sharpe, In the Wake: On Blackness and Being. With majesty, opulence, and agency, Séancers examines how the American racialized body uses psychic, spiritual, and theoretical strategies to shapeshift through loss and oppression. This journey into the surreal and fantastical states of the Black imagination traverses the "fatal" axis of abstraction, illegibility, and gender complexity with a collapsing of lyrical poetry, movement forms, and discursive performance. Jaamil Olawale Kosoko is a Bessie Award nominated Nigerian-American curator, poet, and performance artist. Séancers includes sound artist Jeremy Toussaint-Baptiste and video installation by Andrew Amorim.

performer.perf_name: Hand to Hand: A FringeArts Circus Festival
performer.perf_description: FringeArts and Circadium School of Contemporary Circus present a new, multi-day festival of contemporary circus art. Featuring performances on the FringeArts stage and outside in the Haas Biergarten, Hand to Hand brings remarkable levels of artistry and ability together into one thrilling weekend of events, perfect for the whole family. Performances include aerials, acrobatics, juggling, and everything in between. The internationally renowned, Montreal-based Barcode Circus Company will headline a daring line up of some of the region's most boundary-pushing contemporary circus artists and up-and-coming innovators. The festival also includes free admission performances and an afternoon of family-friendly, outdoor workshops from the Philadelphia School of Circus Arts.

performer.perf_description: Canoe Challenge down the Brandywine benefiting the Cerebral Palsy Association.

performer.perf_description: On Friday, May 11, 2018, we return to the extravagant Annenberg Court at The Barnes Foundation for Moore College of Art & Design's production of "Century 21 Department Store presents Fashion Show 2018." This year, you are sure to be wowed by the collections of our Senior fashion designers, preceded by those created by Juniors. Annenberg Court will be totally reimagined for the event, transformed into a glamorous, dramatically lit setting that will beautifully showcase the garments. Always sold-out, make sure to get your tickets now and at a discount of only $35, as they are $45 at the door. performer.perf_name: Spring Forward Exhibition with Marta Sanchez, Sharon Cosgrove, & Stephen Tippett
performer.perf_description: A group exhibition celebrating the work of renowned contemporary artists Sharon Cosgrove, Marta Sanchez, and Stephen Tippett. Exhibition opening 4/7 from 6-8 PM. Exhibition open from 4/7-4/21. (American Color Print Society Exhibition and Opening will be occurring simultaneously in Gallery One)

Jane Buikstra, Regents' Professor of Bioarchaeology and Founding Director, Center for Bioarchaeological Research in the School of Human Evolution and Social Change at Arizona State University, is renowned for her groundbreaking international research in bioarchaeology, paleopathology, forensic anthropology, and paleodemography. In this talk, Dr. Buikstra focuses on tuberculosis and leprosy, closely related mycobacterial diseases that continue to challenge medical science today. Both are commonly considered Old World diseases, based upon evidence from texts, portable art, murals, and human remains. Focusing upon archaeological and biomolecular approaches, she considers new evidence for the antiquity of these mycobacterial diseases in the Americas. Pre-registration recommended. Free.
Enjoy happy hour with friends--and a martini special, if you like--in the Egypt (Mummies) Gallery. Admission: $9 per person includes one free drink for guests 21 and over.

performer.perf_name: PM @ Penn Museum: Where in the Penn Museum is Carmen Sandiego?
performer.perf_description: Calling all gumshoes! Carmen Sandiego has taken over the Penn Museum along with her henchmen. We need you and your team to help track her down and save the Penn Museum at this special edition program, where guests have fun--and engage in a little competitive rivalry--exploring the galleries and discovering new facts about geography and culture! Adults only (admission includes one drink).

performer.perf_description: Celebrating Volunteer Week: ECS Young Friends Circle will host an Open House and Volunteer Fair to introduce interested individuals to volunteering opportunities with many ECS programs, including: *Out of School Time Programs *The RISE Initiative *Wintershelter *Dolphins Companionship Program *SYS *St. Barnabas Mission *Gift in Kind Program *Community Food Cupboard Location: ECS Main Building 225 South 3rd St. (Greeting space on the Outdoor Patio) Philadelphia, PA 19106.
