performer.perf_description: It's the highly anticipated third annual 4/20 edition of "Weeding Out the Stoned."These have sold out every year. We're doing two shows back-to-back - 8:30 PM and 10 PM. Both shows totally different! Both packed full of surprises. Sixteen comedians enter. All but one of them are stoned. It's up to all of us to find the sober individual so the entire audience can win prizes! Officer Alex Grubard administers field sobriety tests, takes audience testimony, and asks trivia questions of Philly's premier drug-induced comics as we all seek justice by weeding out the stoned.

performer.perf_name: Good Good Presents Robert Dean (Comedy Central)
performer.perf_description: Good Good is excited to host the hilarious Robert Dean in Philly for one night only on his multi-city train tour across the country. Robert Dean is a New York City based stand-up comedian. He has been featured on WNYC's 2 Dope Queens Podcast, AXS TV's Gotham Comedy Live, on Comedy Central Half Hour as Sexy Abraham Lincoln Lobster Man and in 2014 he was named a Comedy Central Comic to Watch. His debut album (It's Not Easy) Being Dean is out on Sure Thing Records and was recorded at 2017's New York Comedy Festival. In recent years Dean has performed at the most renowned shows and venues around the country including Whiplash, Meltdown, Bridgetown Comedy Festival & more.

Please join us as we honor Josey G. Fisher, Director of the Holocaust Oral History Archive of the The Tuttleman Library of Gratz College, and Instructor in Holocaust & Genocide Studies at Gratz College for her exceptional leadership, dedication, and outstanding contributions to benefit the fields of Holocaust studies and education. She will then share her work through "In Their Own Words: Voices of the Holocaust. -This program will take place at the gorgeous Philmont Country Club -Cost: $50 per person -Reservations are required before April 23, 2018 at info@hamec.org or 215.464.4701
Join brewer Kurt Ludwig of Mad Princes Brewing to sample and learn about the history and profile of this unique beer in the beautiful indoor setting of Fonthill Castle.
DJs Little Spaceyy and Nymphaea spin Italian disco and synthpop all night.

Come and discover for yourself the joy and beauty of mathematics! Solve challenging puzzles, build tricky structures, learn fascinating magic tricks, create colorful symmetrical artwork, play games, and most importantly, have fun.
SAINt JHN is a hip-hop artist from Brooklyn.

performer.perf_name: Music at the Museum: An Opera Performance
performer.perf_description: Please join us for a special evening of music and history at the National Museum of Industrial History. Music at the Museum: An Opera Performance with American Baritone Troy Cook, Thursday April 19th, 2018, 6-9pm, at the National Museum of Industrial History in Bethlehem. In 1910, in an effort to boost morale and heal the wounds left behind by a tumultuous strike at the Bethlehem Steel plant, then president Charles Schwab formed the Bethlehem Steel Company Band. The National Museum of Industrial History is bringing music to the museum with a memorable evening featuring a special performance by American baritone Troy Cook of Opera Philadelphia. Guests will have a chance to soothe their souls with elegant performances by Mr. Cook and step back in time to explore the Museum's galleries with expert guides. Wine and light appetizers will be served. All proceeds benefit the Museum's ongoing educational programs and exhibits and the care and preservation of its unique collections. About the Performer: Troy Cook made notable debuts in past seasons as Ford in Hamburgische Staatsoper's Falstaff, following his debut with the company as Marcello in La bohème, and with the Royal Opera, Covent Garden as Guglielmo in Così fan tutte.? Troy began the 2017-2018 season creating the role of John Cree in the world premiere of Elizabeth Cree with Opera Philadelphia. He bows as Enrico in Lucia di Lammermoor with Florida Grand Opera, Rodrigo in Don Carlo with Washington National Opera, and Falke in Die Fledermaus with Utah Opera and Des Moines Metro Opera. He also appears in concert with the Charlotte Symphony and Memphis Symphony for Handel's Messiah. "He has a beautiful, robust, woolen baritone, the sort that flows effortlessly in its middle range, and gathers energy as it climbs higher, never showing the faintest hint of a blemish."-Eric Simpson, The New Criterion Tickets and details available at http://nmih.org/nmihevents/music-at-the-museum-with-troy-cook/

performer.perf_name: First Sunday at Peachfield - Oney Judge, Runaway Slave of Martha Washington
performer.perf_description: Oney Judge was a dower slave owned by the estate of Martha Washington's first husband. When Oney discovered that she was to be a wedding present for Martha's granddaughter, she planned her escape. Hear the tale of Oney's flight to New Hampshire and freedom as portrayed by Alexandra Ford of the American Historical Theatre. Admission is $10 per person for everyone in attendance. Seating is limited; prepaid reservations are required to guarantee seating. Please call 609/267-6996, or email at colonialdamesnj@comcast.net. This event takes place at Peachfield, the Headquarters of The National Society of The Colonial Dames of America in The State of New Jersey, 180 Burrs Road, Westampton, NJ 08060. The New Jersey Dames are collecting non-perishable food and toiletries to help support our community at the Extended Hand Food Pantry in Mount Holly. Please bring your donation to any of our upcoming events. Funding has been made possible in part by the New Jersey Historical Commission, Department of State and the Burlington County Board of Chosen Freeholders, Department of Resource Conservation, Division of Parks.

Experience religious art in the making at Glencairn Museum during its annual Sacred Arts Festival. The festival features an array of demonstrations throughout the afternoon, from glassblowing and icon writing to solo-voice music and the creation of a sand mandala, that give visitors a unique view of many beautiful expressions of faith from various cultures. This event is also a rare opportunity to experience the Museum's vast collection of religious art and artifacts--and the castle itself--while touring its many galleries and public spaces. At their leisure, visitors are invited to explore room by room, take in the exciting view from Glencairn's tower or relax in the Castle Café. Admission includes all festival demonstrations and access to the galleries and the tower as well as the Museum's 15-minute orientation video and cell-phone audio tour of the collections. This year's Sacred Arts Festival includes these demonstrations: *Glassblowing with Jason Klein *Metal forging with Rachel Kedinger *Stained glass painting with J. Kenneth Leap *Sand mandala completion and dismantling with Losang Samten *Icon writing with Susan Kelly vonMedicus *Solo-voice music with Les Canards Chantants *Stone carving with Jens Langlotz *Mosaic making with Carol Stirton-Broad *Replica Gutenberg-era printing press with Kirsten Gyllenhaal *Dance by inFlux Dance Company of Bryn Athyn College. Of special interest are the Tibetan Buddhist sand mandala, created over 5 days and ritually dismantled late Sunday afternoon by The Venerable Lama Losang Samten, and the glassblowing demonstration by Historical Glassworks' Jason Klein, who is working to bring medieval skills back to life while researching the centuries' old striated ruby red glass that Bryn Athyn artisans famously recreated in the early 20th century. Please note: During the festival, the elevator stops only at the 1st and 5th floors and the Tower. Please use the stairs while exploring Glencairn Museum's galleries on all other floors. No strollers or backpack-style baby carriers allowed in the Museum and no wheelchairs permitted beyond the first floor. Photography for private use is permitted. No flash, tripods, selfie-sticks or videography.
performer.perf_keywords: artisan crafts;glencairn museum;glassblowing;stained glass painting;Tibetan sand mandala

performer.perf_name: Art of Bryn Athyn's Nishan Yardumian
performer.perf_description: Glencairn Museum mounts an exhibition of 20 paintings and drawings by the late Bryn Athyn artist and arts instructor Nishan Yardumian (1947-1986). "A Window to the Soul: Nishan Yardumian's Biblical Art" opens Sunday, April 22, during the Museum's annual Sacred Arts Festival and continues through Sunday, November 4, in Glencairn's Upper Hall exhibition space. Yardumian taught painting in Bryn Athyn for many years, at both the Academy of the New Church Secondary Schools and Bryn Athyn College. A painter as well as a teacher, he was passionate about both professions. According to Yardumian, "Painting aims at the universal with the hopes that each individual can find his identification with it. Teaching aims at the individual with the hope of developing the universal." Visitors are welcome to tour the exhibition Tuesday through Friday as part of the Museum's regular 2:30pm "Highlights Tour" and on weekends 1-4:30pm (walk-ins welcome), as well as by appointment and when attending the Sacred Arts and Medieval Festivals. The exhibition is closed April 29 and May 26 for two concerts and on July 4. While there is no charge to view "A Window to the Soul," donations are accepted and access is included in tour and event admission.

performer.perf_name: The Arden Cabaret Series: The Music of Jeanine Tesori
performer.perf_description: Join us to celebrate Jeanine Tesori - from her Tony and Drama Desk Award winning music of Fun Home , and Caroline or Change to Thoroughly Modern Millie, Violet and Shrek the Musical . Arden artists will perform selections from Jeanine's illustrious songbook, in a night that is not to be missed! Evening curated by Music Director Amanda Morton. Additional artists to be announced.

Get up close and personal with one of Glencairn Museum's most popular "sacred arts" artisan crafts this April: the building of a traditional Tibetan Buddhist sand mandala. The Venerable Lama Losang Samten, a Tibetan Buddhist monk who has been demonstrating the making of a sand mandala at the Museum's annual spring Sacred Arts Festival for several years, returns to Glencairn's Great Hall Wednesday through Sunday, April 18-22. Donations welcome April 18-21; included in Sacred Arts Festival admission ($10 adults, $8 seniors/students with ID, free for Museum members & children 3 & under) April 22. The Great Hall is open afternoons for self-guided tours of the space on these days.
performer.perf_keywords: sand mandala;Glencairn Museum;sacred arts;Tibetan Buddhist;Lonsang Samten

performer.perf_name: Philly Cinco de Mayo Bar Crawl
performer.perf_description: This Cinco de Mayo, BarCrawls.com invites you to party like there's no mañana at Philly's second annual Tequila Tour bar crawl. Mark your calendar for Saturday, May 5th as BarCrawls.com presents a Cinco de Mayo party you won't soon forget, highlighted by ticket amenities like cover-free admission to Philadelphia's top bars, taverns, saloons and pubs, plenty of fiesta encounters and sizzling drink specials that are sure to leave you lost in translation. For the Academy of the New Church Secondary Schools' production of Shrek the Musical this April, cast and crew rise to the challenge of quick scene changes, character transformations, a large and rollicking cast--and a "fire-breathing" dragon. Opening 8pm Friday, April 20, at Bryn Athyn's Mitchell Performing Arts Center (MPAC), Shrek the Musical is a Tony Award-winning fairy tale adventure based on the Oscar-winning DreamWorks Animation film and featuring all new songs from Jeanine Tesori (Thoroughly Modern Millie; Caroline, or Change). The show continues with four more performances: 7pm Saturday, April 21; 2pm Sunday, April 22; 8pm Friday, April 27; and 7pm Saturday, April 28. Purchase tickets online at www.ANCSS.org, by phone at 267.502.4810 or at the door. Use the coupon code "ShrekFirstFriday" at checkout for a $4 discount on each opening night ticket. "Shrek's an entertaining show for audiences of all ages--lots of laughs, great songs and a strong message of inclusion and acceptance," says Sarah Cooper Waelchli, producer.

Step back in time to 19th century Philadelphia and experience life for the rising middle class during the Victorian era. In addition to viewing the Mansion's Victorian rooms, guests enjoy Victoriana Reimagined, an art exhibition by three contemporary artists inspired by the historic interiors of Ebenezer Maxwell Mansion. Presented in Spanish.

performer.perf_name: The Wilma Theater's Theater Lovers Fete
performer.perf_description: The Wilma Theater's annual fundraising party, Theater Lovers Fête, will be honoring Artistic Director Blanka Zizka on Monday, May 14, 2018 at 5:30pm at the newly anointed Wilma at Aurora on 265 South Broad Street, Philadelphia, PA 19107. The Wilma will be celebrating their visionary leader, the Wilma's transformation, and a future of exceptional artistic invention. Relish every moment of the Theater Lovers Fête, enjoying fine fare, cocktails, and pop-up performances. The honorary co-chairs of the event are Linda and David Glickstein, David Haas, and Leonard C. Haas. Tickets are $250 per person. For more info, please visit wilmafete.org.

Join The Galleries as we welcome Anita Sarkeesian -- award-winning media critic and the creator and executive director of Feminist Frequency, an educational nonprofit that explores the representations of women in pop culture narratives. Her work focuses on deconstructing the stereotypes and tropes associated with women in popular culture as well as highlighting issues surrounding the targeted harassment of women in online and gaming spaces. She has been a panelist at the United Nations and been a guest speaker at various fan, media and technology conferences including XOXO, The Media Evolution Conference, Women in the World and GeekGirlCon. Anita has been interviewed and featured in publications such as Wired, The Guardian, Rolling Stone, The Wall Street Journal, The New York Times and The Colbert Report. Anita was named one of TIME's 100 most influential people in the world in 2015 and was the recipient of the 2014 Game Developers Choice Ambassador Award. In 2016 Anita was awarded an honorary PhD from The New School in New York City.
A struggling actress encounters an old colleague and joins him and his criminal sidekick for a series of wacky adventures through the city.

Nashville North Studios is beginning their spring with a buzz...."Sugar Buzz" that is, a group exhibition in the main studio, along with a solo exhibit of beautiful works by Stan Sperlak. Mr. Sperlak is a regionally and nationally respected pastel painter, having recently been accepted into the Pastel Society of America as a juried member. He is also on the Board of Directors of the Mid Atlantic Plein Air Painters Association and has been teaching workshops across the country and at his farm near Cape May, NJ. His works have appeared in numerous magazines and books on painting. Sperlak studied at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts and at the Barn Studio of Art in Millville, NJ with Pat Witt. He joins NNS with his vision of our world...and it is a breathtaking journey that you don't want to miss. Our musicians of the month, Danny Godbey and MQ Murphy, will entertain you with original music that not only tells a story, buy draws you in and encourages you to participate! And maybe Ms. Dollak will do a reading. That's what all the Buzz is about. Nashville North Studios' list of artists is growing and includes some of the best that our South Jersey area has to offer. Many show their works at The Ocean City Fine Arts League, The Ocean City Art Center, Great Bay Gallery, The Riverfront Renaissance Center, The Philadelphia Museum of Art, The Noyes Museum, Biscayne Nature Center and many venues far from our area. We welcome everyone to stop by for our opening or during regular business hours, Tuesday - Saturday from 12 - 6 pm. The Fourth Friday Artists Reception will take place on April 27th from 6 until 8:00 pm at Nashville North Studios, Suite 8, Linwood Greene, 210 New Road, Linwood, NJ 08221. For more information please contact Judy Saylor and/or Jim Allison at 609-504-5044. This event is free and open to the public. Light refreshments will be served.

Everything in one place to create your dream day! Love Local Wed Local Admission is free. Advance registration is suggested. Complimentary Valet parking. Participating Vendors: Thornbury Farm, Delightful Desserts & Culinary Creations Events for Classic Catering, Allegro Music Entertainment, Calligraphy by Crawford, Carousel Ballroom, Chariot Photo Booth, Chariot Valet, Decorative Edges, Dream Vacations - Peabody Travel, Flowers by Kim Walle, Flutter Social, Hattie Weselyk Studio, Harvest Ridge Winery, Home Brewed Events, Holmespun, Live Lovely Beauty, Mid Atlantic Limo, Sas Becker Photography, Scott Entertainment, The New Locals band, The Party Center, United Site Services, Uprooted, Will Clemens, Officiant

Admission is $25, and 100% of proceeds will benefit America's first animal refuge, Morris Animal Shelter. Bring your yoga mat and get ready to meet some tiny puppies! These offerings typically sell out within a week, so what are you waiting for!? Save the date and join us at this wonderful event! Visit the link for tickets. Please note: We cannot accommodate any dogs from the public under any circumstance. This event is meant to promote the adoption of homeless dogs housed at Morris Animal Refuge. Thank you for understanding.

performer.perf_name: Truths of the Trade: Seeing Slavery in the Winterthur Collection
performer.perf_description: A newly acquired cabinet at Winterthur and related objects in the collection emerge as tools in the lucrative business of transatlantic trade in the 18th and 19th centuries. Curated by graduate students at Winterthur, this exhibit will be on view in the Society of Winterthur Fellows Gallery. Members free. Included with admission.

performer.perf_name: No Dog Left Behind 7th Annual Spring Fling Charity Event
performer.perf_description: Tickets to the annual No Dog Left Behind fundraiser gets you the perfect night out and helps support our military. The ticket price is just $60 per person for a full night of: food, open bar, free parking, great music, a chance to mingle with soldiers and their dogs, raffle prizes and a guest speaker.

The 5th Clinical Regulatory Medical Writing Forum is designed to provide attendees with the strategies and insights needed to efficiently compose clinical regulatory documents, manage in-house and external resources, effectively execute the writing process, and understand the recent developments in regulations.

Two of the Secret Cinema's favorite types of films to show are musical shorts and cartoons. Yet, the two genres have a lengthy, deep and harmonious (sorry!) history together, beginning in the earliest days of sound animation. Both Walt Disney's "Steamboat Willie" and Max Fleischer's "My Old Kentucky Home" used popular music as a central theme. The latter film was from Fleischer's "Song Car-Tunes" series, and featured bouncing ball lyrics, an innovation patented by Max. Many sound cartoons from the 1930s featured a non-stop soundtrack of hot jazz or other pop music of its time, with the animated portion of a theater's selected short subjects serving as the MTV of its time. Other cartoons made music part of their plots, or featured caricatures and even live-action appearances of famous singers and musicians. Tonight, Secret Cinema will be screening a variety of cartoons from several of the top animation studios of the classic era, from the 1920s through the 1950s (and perhaps a few examples from the post-classic era). All feature music or musicians, including jazz, swing, and opera (!), on the soundtracks and in story lines. As usual, this Secret Cinema program will be projected in 16mm film on a giant screen (not video).

performer.perf_name: CASA Youth Advocates 3rd Annual Superhero 5K Run/Walk
performer.perf_description: On Sunday, April 29, at 9:00 a.m. at Ridley Creek State Park in Media, runners and walkers dressed in superhero costumes will gather in support of CASA Youth Advocates, a Media, PA-based organization whose mission is to champion children in Delaware and Chester counties' child welfare systems. CASA Youth Advocates recruits, trains, and supports volunteer Court Appointed Special Advocates who work to ensure that abused and neglected children in Delaware and Chester Counties' child welfare systems find a safe, permanent, and nurturing home. CASA served 206 of our region's vulnerable children in 2017, nearly doubling the number of cases served in the last ten years, yet that is still less than 20% of the children who could benefit from the support of a CASA volunteer. That's where fundraising events like the 3rd Annual Superhero 5K Run and Walk play an important role. Emmy Award winning FOX29 News Reporter Chris O'Connell will join us again during this year's festivities to help us kick-off the start of the race. He adds, "CASA Youth Advocates does some amazing work. They are the unsung heroes to our most vulnerable children." Each 5K registrant receives a t-shirt, refreshments, water stations, and prizes. The event includes awards for the top overall male and female race finishers, overall age group winners, best costume (for both humans and pets) and top sponsors. Timing and logistics will be coordinated by Bryn Mawr Racing Company. Awards: Top overall male/female race finishers, overall age group winners, best costume (for both humans and pets) and top 1-3 sponsors.

The Third Annual #RISE Youth Summit is here. Let's #RISE into action! This year's summit will feature workshops on media, youth empowerment, community advocacy, and policy. Free entry, free swag, giveaways, free meals and more. Register today! The youth summit is open to youth ages 13 -18 years old. Adult Chaperones with youth group (5 youth minimum) are allowed to attend the summit as volunteers. (Youth groups and adult chaperones must register by May 4th.) The #RealTalkTobacco #RISE Youth Summit is a convening of 150 youth leaders from around the Philadelphia and Southeastern PA area who are currently engaged in or are passionate about public health advocacy work including tobacco control and prevention. The annual youth summit features special guest speakers conducting workshops on advanced advocacy content including: Social Media, Policy, Storytelling, Tobacco and Advocacy 101(Youth Empowerment). In today's Philadelphia, youth face a common crisis: the fight for a healthy and safe future. Our Advocacy Institute youth understand that their best chance to fight against health disparities and social injustices is to organize, mobilize, and advocate in solidarity. This summit is an opportunity for our AI Ambassadors and Summit guest speakers to equip rising youth leaders with the tools they need to stand together in the fight against Big Tobacco and any other industry or social system that prevents their communities from achieving health equity.

On Sunday May 13th celebrate Mother's Day with all of the amazing moms from across the animal kingdom! Enjoy a delicious unlimited brunch buffet offered at three available seating times, visit with your favorite animals and learn from the experts who care for them at the Zoo. Visit PECO Primate Reserve to meet gorilla moms Kira and Honi, and their toddlers Amani and Ajabu as they swing, stroll and explore their exhibits. Check out all of the amazing moms that call Philadelphia Zoo home. Advance registration is required and availability is limited. Visit www.PhiladelphiaZoo.org to purchase tickets.

Introducing Jokes at Connie's! A monthly comedy showcase/open mic at Connie's Ric Rac. Join us for our second showcase featuring: Sylis P, Megan Goetz, Charles Blyzniuk and Brian Isley. performer.perf_name: Lecture: Longfellow, Paul Revere, & the Creation of an American Mythology
performer.perf_description: Lecturer: Steve Wills, education consultant and former director, Wachovia Teacher Resource Center, Philadelphia Museum of Art. In the 1800s, our young nation's cultural history began with heroes and mythology created by writers such as James Fennimore Cooper, who gave us Hawkeye, and Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, who commemorated Paul Revere. This presentation will highlight these early tales of ingenuity, confidence, independence, optimism and grit - viewed in the context of the creation of an American Spirit.

performer.perf_name: Friday Night Jazz - Bessie Smith & Etta James: Queens of the Blues
performer.perf_description: The magnetic and passionate voices of Sherry Butler and Suzanne Burgess pay tribute to these queens of the blues. An evening of captivating jazz tunes and soulful melodies with "At Last," "I Just Want to Make Love to You," and more.

performer.perf_name: Friday Night Jazz - Sarah Vaughan: Sassy Velvet
performer.perf_description: Vocalist Geri Oliver brings alive Sarah Vaughan with American songbook tunes like "Misty," "The Nearness of You," Day by Day" and more.

performer.perf_name: Friday Night Jazz - Lou Rawls: The Original Soul Man
performer.perf_description: Lou Rawls used his voice to tell life's stories of love and heartache with equal passion. Charismatic vocalist El Barak and the Arpeggio Jazz Ensemble perform Rawls's classic hits "I'd Rather Drink Muddy Water," "Love Is a Hurtin'," "Feelin'," "Tobacco Road," "Stormy Monday," and others.

performer.perf_name: Friday Night Jazz - Jazz Mamas: Nurturing Jazz
performer.perf_description: Vocalists Jeannie Brooks, Mi'cal Beckham, and Suzanne Burgess and poet Lauren NeFesha pay tribute to Dinah Washington, Anita O'Day, Nancy Wilson, Abbey Lincoln, Carmen McCrae, and Peggy Lee who nurtured jazz in many hearts. Songs like "Fever," "Route 66," "Guess Who I Saw Today," "All of Me," remind us of the amazing spirit of these "jazz mamas."

performer.perf_name: Friday Night Jazz - Sonny Rollins: Saxophone Colossus
performer.perf_description: A tribute to Sonny Rollins, one of the true giants of jazz saxophone. Rollins has been an influence and collaborator with luminaries John Coltrane, Dexter Gordon, Clifford Jordan, and others. Saxophonist Umar Raheem presents Rollins favorites "Saint Thomas" and "Doxy," and his many forays into the Wild West.

performer.perf_name: Friday Night Jazz - Motown Meets Jazz
performer.perf_description: Relive those good times with Motown classics by the Temptations, Martha and the Vandellas, the Supremes, Smokey Robinson and the Miracles, and others. Tunes such as "Papa Was a Rolling Stone," "Heat Wave," "Where Did Our Love Go?," and "Oooh, Baby, Baby" will open the floodgates of your memories.

performer.perf_name: Friday Night Jazz - Have A Good Time, New Orleans Style
performer.perf_description: Featuring the festive music of New Orleans legends Louis (Satchmo) Armstrong, Jelly Roll Morton, Gary U.S. Bonds, and other legends. Tunes like "Honeysuckle Rose," "Seven-Day Weekend," "Bourbon Street Parade," and more will guarantee a good time for all.

performer.perf_name: Tuesday Nights at the Movies: International House
performer.perf_description: A prototype for an invention not unlike television wreaks havoc at a Chinese hotel. WC Fields stars along with Bela Lugosi, George Burns, Gracie Allen, and Cab Calloway (singing "Reefer Man") in this spunky, somewhat risqué pre-code comedy. (1933/70 minutes)

performer.perf_name: Tuesday Nights at the Movies: Le Samourai
performer.perf_description: Alain Delon is an enigmatic and taciturn hitman who lives by his own austere code of ethics. He becomes dangerously enmeshed with an exotic nightclub singer in this stylish psychological crime thriller. This hugely influential color neo-noir deconstructs the imagery of hardboiled Hollywood into a poetic and lucid dream often imitated but never duplicated. In French with English subtitles. 2017-18 season finale. (1967/105 minutes)

Come join us for the 31st Annual Tour de Shore! This exciting 50 or 65 mile bike ride will take over 3,000 riders from Philadelphia or Berlin, NJ to Atlantic City. Upon arrival in Atlantic City, at our legendary after party, riders, volunteers, supporters, and friends & family come together to celebrate the amazing physical accomplishment of our participants and raise even more for our worthy causes. All proceeds will benefit the Tour de Shore Children's Foundation and our goal of raising $1,250,000 in 2018 for local children's charities and the families of fallen first responders in the Philadelphia and South Jersey area.

Since 2009 the Tour de Shore Children's Foundation has been hosting the Gathering of Heroes fundraising event. This guest bartending event held at the Irish Pub features Medal of Honor recipients, local government and law enforcement officials, and countless military men and women. Through sponsorships, donations, bartender tips, and silent and live auctions we raise money for the Marine Corps-Law Enforcement Foundation (MC-LEF), a non-profit organization that gives scholarships to every child who loses a parent while serving in the United States Marine Corps or any Federal Law Enforcement Agency. In 2017 we raised over $50,000 in one night for MC-LEF, bringing our total raised to $320,000!
performer.perf_keywords: military;medal of honor;irish pub;fundraiser;guest bartending;frist responders;philadelphia

performer.perf_description: Explore the Scott Arboretum's early spring blooms with an expert staff leader. This tour is geared for gardeners from beginners to experts.

Invented by and meant for gardeners, hypertufa troughs have an appearance similar to limestone planters but without the weight and expense. Learn about the science behind hypertufa and create your own weather-resistant planting trough to take home. Join in the fun and laugh your stress away at the Philadelphia Area World Laughter Day Celebration on Sunday, May 6, 2018 from 1:00-3:00 PM at the Smith Memorial Playground in East Fairmount Park, just above Kelly Drive near 33rd and Oxford Streets. In case of inclement weather, the celebration will be moved inside to the 2nd floor of the Smith Mansion Playhouse. It's fun, free and everyone is invited! No experience necessary. Special guests will be on-hand to open our celebration with a welcome speech. This will be followed by a 1-hour Laughter Yoga exercise session, co-hosted by Laughter Yoga Teachers Alexa Drubay and Bill Powell (Philadelphia Parks and Recreation Performing Arts Coordinator). Other area Laughter Yoga professionals will also be present to help lead the session. We will end with a mindfulness meditation focusing on world peace, which will be guided by Philadelphia Yoga legend Jennifer Schelter. World Laughter Day (WLD) is celebrated the first Sunday in May all over the world. This annual celebration was created in 1998 by cardiologist Dr. Madan Kataria, who also founded the internationally acclaimed Laughter Yoga movement in 1995. Today, and in its 23rd year, Laughter Yoga is practiced in 108 countries and at over 6000 laughter clubs. Look out for WLD events being celebrated in Paris, Tokyo, Sydney, Toronto, Berlin, Frankfurt, Taipei, Rome, Hong Kong, and other cities. The celebration of World Laughter Day is a positive manifestation for world peace and is intended to build up a global consciousness of unity and friendship through laughter. Philadelphia participants will be able to pick up Laughter Yoga health and resilience packets, as well as area laughter club listings at our info booth. Local sponsors will also provide snacks and water. Thanks to Smith Memorial Playground, Repatriation Group International, the Delaware County Parks and Recreation and local businesses, for supporting our event.

Local and out of state designers and vendors will be in attendance to premiere their clothing lines and products. $30 general admission; $50 VIP admission VIP includes table seat, complimentary food and drinks, swag bag, and more.

June 14th: "Baked & Bottled" The Newlin staff will be firing up the reconstructed outdoor bake oven to make a variety of fresh bread. Chat with them while sipping wine from Penns Woods Winery. Newlin Grist Mill and Wild Birds Unlimited-Concordville are teaming up to explore the wonderful world of bird life. Join us for monthly naturalist-led walks through the 160-acre park at Newlin Grist Mill. We will meet year-round residents, visit exciting migrants, and learn the basics of bird identification and biology. Families and beginners are welcome! This year Pinnacle Parkour Academy will be offering not one but three Summer camp weeks to choose from. Early Bird pricing starting at $250/week. Camp pricing will go up $50 every month for their respective weeks starting on the following days: Week 1 - $350 until 4/25; Week 2 - $300 until 4/23; Week 3 - $250 until 4/27. The curriculum for Summer Camp 2018 is based on Ukemi - the Discipline of Falling. Failure is an essential element of any learning process and the movement art of failure is known as Ukemi. Ukemi is a Japanese word that means "breaking ones fall" and is used to describe a method of falling without getting injured. The method originated in martial art styles including judo, aikido, jujitsu, and wushu and has since been translated over to other sports including parkour. Ukemi was designed to study falling techniques related to specific scenarios of a specific sport. In aikido, ukemi is used to practice falling out of "uncontrolled" throws safely. A similar example in parkour ukemi, would be failing a front flip and instead of landing on your head, you turn it into a dive roll. Failing is a part of every sport and learning how to fail safely is one of the most important skills that we can learn as athletes. Summer Camp will run from 9 AM - 3 PM, Monday through Friday. We will be providing lunch for the kids each day, and they are free to bring whatever extra snacks they wish. We are asking that everyone bring a water bottle, and wear athletic clothing and sneakers. (Absolutely no flip-flops, sandals, or crocs)

In 2018, our naturalist will pop-up from 1pm to 5pm on the following Saturdays: April 28: "Animal Homes"; May 26: "Wonderful Wildflowers"; June 30: "Frogs & Toads"; July 28: "Plant Superheroes"; August 25: "Stream Life"; September 29: "Persistent Pollinators"; October 27: "Mighty Oaks"

For the past fifteen years, New Hope Celebrates has hosted one of the first Prides of the season in May. Usually held in June, there are over 1,000 annual Pride celebrations worldwide. Set in the lush greenery of the Delaware River Valley, our Pride festival connects two towns in two different states by the New Hope & Lambertville Bridge. Drawing more than 15,000 people annually, New Hope Celebrates joins together the LGBT friendly towns of Lambertville, NJ and New Hope, PA.

Join the Delaware River Towns Chamber of Commerce and New Hope Celebrates as we kick off Pride Fest 2018 with a 5K Run and a 1 Mile Health Walk. The course will take runners across the historic and charming Lambertville-New Hope Bridge, through the streets of bustling and festive downtown of New Hope, back across the Lambertville/New Hope Bridge and through Lambertville's historic downtown business district. The event is sure to draw hundreds of supporters. Be sure to wear your best PRIDE colors as we celebrate diversity and inclusiveness in our community.

Join us on Earth Day, Sunday, April 22 when it's high time for a low-tide clean-up of the Delaware River shoreline at Fort Mifflin! Celebrate Earth Day in the unique environment along the banks of the Delaware River just off the High Battery. Trash and debris removal plus trail maintenance will get this nature area in top shape to be a regular feature for visitors this spring and summer. Wear comfortable work clothes, no sandals. Bring work gloves if you have them. Registration begins at noon, with work from 1 till 4 PM. Students & Scouts are welcome with parental supervision. Can't make it for the afternoon work session but still want to be a part of this event? Come for the concert! Concert-only tickets will be available on site for a suggested donation of $20. Exhibition Dates: April 4-29. First Friday: April 6, 5-9. Reception: Sunday April 8, 12-4. Gallery Hours: Wednesday-Sunday 12-5PM. Conny Parsons presents a series of large oil paintings that are visually or physically split. Parsons references objects in and aspects of nature such as stones, earth, wind, air and water. Like or dissimilar natural objects are shifted or joined into a whole that is greater than the components. Like objects are repeated, reversed or misplaced. Dissimilar images are joined in a cohesive way through color, shapes, movement, transparency, and repetition. This series is about the continual change in the primitive, natural world. The artist allowed imagery to happen as she painted and playfully terms the resulting series as "Organized Chaos".

Exhibition Dates: April 4-29. First Friday: April 6, 5-9. Reception: Sunday April 8, 12-4. Gallery Hours: Wednesday-Sunday 12-5PM. Alleger's work incorporates her travels and she has begun a series of projects entitled Wanderlust for each locale that she visits. She asks herself "What happens when I step out of my daily routine and step into the unknown?" Travel allows her the opportunity to slow down and observe a new culture and speculate about daily life there. Her newest series Wanderlust: Iceland is a yearlong reflection of how a once sleepy little village has been flooded by visitors. She embraces the beauty of the landscape and quaint homes, while grappling with the impact tourism has had on the country. While speculating on daily life in Reykjavik, the capital and largest city, she was confronted with the realization that the entire city was consumed with the tourism industry. Its cultural identity was being over shadowed by a need to cater to its visitors. Development brought benefits but also negatives like rising costs and need to maintain new infrastructure. What will happen if and when this bubble bursts? Jasmine Alleger has a MFA in Studio Art, 2013 from Moore College of Art and Design, Philadelphia, PA and a BS in Drawing and Painting, 2010 from Portland State University Portland, OR.

Appearing in a rare acoustic setting, Phil Joel with Zealand Worship will perform at Souderton Mennonite Church Saturday, May 19, 2018, at 7:00 p.m. Doors open at 6:30 p.m. Advance tickets are available for purchase online at http://bit.ly/ZealandSMC or in person at the Souderton Mennonite Church office, located at 105 West Chestnut Street, Souderton, Tuesdays through Thursdays from 9:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. and Fridays 9:00 a.m. to 12:30 p.m.

performer.perf_name: Best Foot Forward: Empowering Women of All Ages
performer.perf_description: Best Foot Forward: Empowering Women of All Ages, presented by Bucks County non-profit Sisters U, returns to the Upper Bucks Campus of Bucks County Community College, 1 Hillendale Drive, Perkasie, from 6 - 8:30 p.m. on Saturday, May 5, 2018. In keeping with the theme of connecting, empowering, and inspiring, the evening will include a keynote from Diane M. Ellis-Marseglia, Bucks County Commissioner, and the presentation of the inaugural Empowered Woman of the Year award to Martha Otto. The evening includes a panel featuring Mackenzie Barth, a women's fashion designer for a global lifestyle company, and Taylor Sison, whose YouTube channel -- where she shares her typical college days, fashion finds, and other tips -- has over 20,000 subscribers. In addition to vendors and raffles, attendees will enjoy a fashion show presented by Frox, featuring clothing from Frox, Dani's Eco-Chic Resale, Peach and many other local boutiques, with members of the community walking the runway as models. "Best Foot Forward is designed to showcase the versatility of Sisters U and of women in general," said Sisters U founder and CEO, Karen Chellew. "The event gives opportunities to learn something new, be creative, get inspired, and have fun. It's perfect for a girls' night, a mother-daughter night, you name it. Join us!" To join our sponsors - Bucks County Community College, Thrivent Financial, QNB, Upper Bucks YMCA, Penn Community Bank, ServPro Upper Bucks, and Cosmetic and Family Dentistry of Perkasie -- or to purchase tickets, visit sistersu.com/best-foot-forward. Sisters U is a 501(c)3 based in Perkasie, Pennsylvania committed to connecting and empowering individual women to be their authentic selves and reach their full potential. The funds raised from this event will continue to support Sisters U's mission of providing monthly women's programming, workshops, and community outreach.

performer.perf_name: Beethoven to Brahms... & E.T. A. Hoffmann
performer.perf_description: A special concert presentation expanded with historic imagery and descriptive discourse, with piano, violin and cello. Music: E.T.A. Hoffmann: Grand Piano Trio in E Major; Beethoven: Piano Sonata in E major, op. 109; Brahms: Piano Trio #1 in B major, Schumann: Adagio and Allegro for cello and piano. We jump back to the dawn of the 19th century and visit a fascinating series of connections around the explosion of musical romanticism in "Beethoven to Brahms," framed with notions about artistic spirit in art and music.This will be highlighted through the lens of the unique writer E.T.A. Hoffmann (who wrote "The Nutcracker" and other fantastical tales), a man who deeply loved music and wanted to be a professional composer. Great music within an expanded lecture + visual presentation, this concert will be a glorious sharing of splendid works in which to immerse oneself. Two performances, two venues: 5/19, 7:30 p.m. at Ivy Hall - International Institute for Culture and 5/20, 3 p.m, Ethical Society Building. Tickets: TICKETS: https://fineartmusiccompany.ticketleap.com.

performer.perf_name: Love Sucks. Let's Sing! A Cabaret
performer.perf_description: Join us for a cabaret song cycle starring The Cabaret Divas, Jean Brooks and Debra Leigh Scott, that explores the beautiful, the poignant, the funny and the just plain awful aspects of love. Musical material ranges from Broadway to American songbook to rock 'n roll to folk. Jeff McDonnell is the music director and accompanist. Tour our stunning and ever-expanding Tree Peony Collection at the peak of bloom. Explore the collection with experts from the Mid-Atlantic Peony Society and stay for a reception in the Wister Center with like-minded gardening enthusiasts.

Your helical heart is everywhere. Your blood is the transport system of your needs. Your vessels draw you toward and away. Created by Nicole Bindler with the performers. Music by Julius Masri. Blood, Sea is an improvised ensemble dance drawing inspiration from our evolution from the ocean to land, our ontogenetic journey from the amniotic sea of the womb to adulthood, and polarities within our lives and bodies, such as affinity and aversion, or blood and cerebrospinal fluid, which arise in the front and back of our bodies, respectively, and are the heaviest and lightest fluids.

The play is set in the mythical town of Almost, Maine, on a cold wintry night with the Northern lights hovering above. It is a compilation of nine whimsically romantic vignettes in which residents of Almost fall in and out of love in unexpected and often hilarious ways. Audiences should expect the unexpected while watching this show, and be ready to sit back and enjoy the ride.

Casual evening wear is requested. A tux would be even better.

Are you interested in sharing your writing with others? The Wordsmiths are reviving their monthly meetup & we would love for you to attend! performer.perf_name: Tribute To Frank Sinatra Starring Tony Sands: It Was A Very Good Year
performer.perf_description: You'll never get a chance to see Frank Sinatra or even Frank Sinatra Jr. perform in concert, but some people say that Tony Sands is the next best thing. He's incorporated stunning graphics that'll entice you the moment the stage lights dim and the music begins. Sands is known not only for his uncanny vocal re-creation of Sinatra but for his mannerisms that help create the illusion that Ol' Blue Eyes is back. Expect hits such as "That's Life," "Come Fly With Me," "Luck Be A Lady"," My Way," "New York New York" and many more. Sands will be accompanied by his six piece big band, so don't miss this one of a kind musical tribute to Sinatra... it's as if Frank walked off the screen and onto the stage.

Justin Hayward is best known as The Moody Blues' vocalist and guitarist and has also enjoyed success with solo projects. He's penned the timeless classics "Nights In White Satin," "Tuesday Afternoon," "The Voice" and "Your Wildest Dreams" and sold over 55 million albums with The Moody Blues. Justin Hayward returns as part of his acoustic trio for one of our fastest-selling shows. In addition to playing lead guitar for Justin Hayward's touring band, Mike Dawes is an acclaimed solo artist plus is hailed as one of the world's finest modern finger style guitarists and performers.

performer.perf_name: The Earls of Leicester Presented By Jerry Douglas
performer.perf_description: Bluegrass all stars perform the music of Lester Flatt & Earl Scrugg. With their second album 'Rattle & Roar,' The Earls have conjured up a fresh batch of Lester Flatt and Earl Scruggs songs, delivered with The Earls' now signature blend of homage, virtuosity and perspective. The Earls of Leicester have discovered a kind of magic that allows moments once relegated to memories to roar back to life. Suddenly, as we listen to and watch The Earls pick, saw and croon, instead of contemplating once upon a time, we are living it.

The Quebe Sisters are triple threat fiddle champions known for their exquisite playing and singing in multi-part close harmony. They've shared stages with music legends like Willie Nelson, Merle Haggard, George Strait, Ricky Skaggs, Ray Price, Connie Smith, Marty Stuart and Asleep At The Wheel. Texas natives Grace, Sophia and Hulda Quebe have released three acclaimed albums and headline shows to an ever growing fanbase.

Gaining popularity with their TLC reality show, The Willis Clan is a Nashville family of 12 brothers and sisters. The Willis' became a household name after receiving national attention as contestants on America's Got Talent and they've performed more than 60 times at The Grand Ole Opry. Their albums are written, performed, engineered and produced by various members of the 14 person family and their live shows are full of meaningful songs, striking harmonies, driving rhythms and soaring anthems which also demonstrate their Irish music and dancing roots.

Gaining popularity with their TLC reality show, The Willis Clan is a Nashville family of 12 brothers and sisters. The Willis' became a household name after receiving national attention as contestants on America's Got Talent and they've performed more than 60 times at The Grand Ole Opry. Their albums are written, performed, engineered and produced by various members of the 14 person family and their live shows are full of meaningful songs, striking harmonies, driving rhythms and soaring anthems which also demonstrate their Irish music and dancing roots.

Only Nashville could give birth to a band like the SteelDrivers, a group of seasoned veterans each distinguished in his or her own right and each valued in Nashville's musical community. They are braiding their bluegrass roots with new threads of their own design, bringing together country, soul and other contemporary influences to create a hybrid that is new music with the old feeling. The SteelDrivers were quickly noticed and have been nominated for Grammys, IBMA awards and the Americana Music Association's New Artist Of The Year. They were presented the International Bluegrass Music Association's award for Emerging Artist Of The Year in 2009. They have performed on numerous radio and TV shows ranging from The Grand Ole Opry to NPR's Mountain Stage. Don't miss their long awaited return to Sellersville!
